Used Cooking Oil Becomes the Latest Flashpoint in U.S.–China Trade Battle

Corryn La Rue
Posted: October 16, 2025

Share:

Reuters photo

Reuters photo

President Donald Trump said Tuesday he’s considering blocking imports of used cooking oil from China in response to the country cutting off all purchases of U.S. soybeans.

“I believe that China purposefully not buying our Soybeans, and causing difficulty for our Soybean Farmers, is an Economically Hostile Act,” Trump wrote on Truth Social Tuesday. “We are considering terminating business with China having to do with Cooking Oil, and other elements of Trade, as retribution.”

The president is referencing the commodity of used cooking oil. Used cooking oil (often shortened to UCO) is vegetable oil or animal fat that has already been used for cooking or frying food. After it’s used, instead of being thrown away, it can be collected, filtered, and processed for reuse—most commonly as a feedstock for renewable fuels.

The United States—a nation of plentiful restaurants, fast food joints, and deep-fried treats imports a waste commodity that’s domestically abundant. You’re not alone in raising an eyebrow at that fact, it’s an interesting trade practice. 

Let’s start with the purpose of acquiring UCO. The United States imports large volumes of used cooking oil to make renewable diesel and sustainable aviation fuel. Because used cooking oil is a waste-based feedstock, it qualified for compliance credits under the Renewable Fuel Standard up until recently. Over the summer, Congress passed a major package of tax and clean energy reforms that tightened eligibility for the clean fuel production credit (45Z). Trump’s “Big Beautiful Bill” includes a provision disqualifying certain imported feedstocks—such as Chinese UCO and foreign tallow—from receiving U.S. clean fuel incentives. Now, regulatory agencies work to develop the legal framework to enforce these changes. 

Imports surged beginning in 2021–2022 as U.S. renewable diesel capacity ramped up. China supplies roughly 60–70 percent of U.S. imports, helped by its large population and restaurant sector, lower collection costs, and established export logistics. It’s important to note China has drastically different labor laws than the U.S., allowing for low labor costs, which translates into a cheaper product. Refineries operated by companies such as Neste, Marathon, and Diamond Green Diesel lean on these readily available and cost-saving streams to keep units running. 

On its face, the financial logic could be straightforward: imported UCO is plentiful, relatively cheap per gallon, and is integrated into efficient export supply chains. The economics favor imports in the short run. Shipping and landed costs for foreign UCO can keep delivered material in the neighborhood of roughly the low-$1s per gallon equivalent, while a new U.S. pre-treatment plant requires $10–$20 million for a 5–10 million gallon unit and $40–$80 million for a 50–100 million gallon unit, even if operating costs are only a few dimes per gallon once built.

Carbon is where domestic supply holds a clear advantage. UCO collected at home for renewable diesel commonly certifies at very low carbon intensities because trucks travel shorter distances and pre-treatment loads are modest. Meanwhile imported streams can score materially higher after ocean shipping and foreign energy mixes are included. As a simple illustration, replacing half of a recent record import year’s UCO volumes with domestic supply would reduce three-quarters of a million metric tons of CO₂ annually, even before considering any batches that might be misclassified abroad. Avoiding a single large trans-Pacific shipment can eliminate several thousand tons of CO₂ tied solely to freight.

While this seems like a no-brainer to farm country, some industry groups (notably parts of the refining/oil sector) push back, arguing that U.S. supply won’t suffice to meet mandated blending volumes without imports.

Its not that domestic collection isn’t occurring, many American firms already source and process domestic UCO. Darling Ingredients, through its DAR PRO network, collects restaurant grease nationwide and supplies Diamond Green Diesel. Chevron’s Renewable Energy Group operates plants that pre-treat and convert U.S. waste oils, including through SeQuential on the West Coast. Mahoney Environmental partners with national chains, and regional firms like Baker Commodities and others round out collection. The domestic system spans about 15 states with significant collection and pre-treatment capacity—Texas, Iowa, Illinois, California, Missouri, Minnesota, Louisiana, Oregon, Washington, Alabama, Georgia, Florida, New York, Pennsylvania, and Nebraska—yet it is not large enough to meet the pace of renewable diesel expansion.

Could the U.S. find more supply at home? Potentially, but only with better infrastructure. Gaps persist in rural pickups, small-restaurant access, and institutional generators like schools, prisons, and military bases. Additional aggregation hubs, standardized pickup systems and containers, more pre-treatment capacity, and modern traceability tools could unlock significant volumes. Policy that specifically rewards U.S.-sourced waste oil—alongside grants or financing for new pre-treat units—would accelerate build-out. The biggest untapped opportunities sit in the Southeast; dense but under-captured urban corridors of the Midwest and Rust Belt; the Southwest and Mountain West where oil often travels long distances for cleaning; large institutional kitchens; and at major ports where cruise and shipping operations generate recoverable oil. With the right logistics and incentives, the United States could plausibly double or even triple current domestic recovery, reducing dependence on imports while supporting farm markets and local jobs.

Quality and processing details shape the debate. China generally cleans and dehydrates UCO before export to meet basic specifications, but what arrives is still a technical feedstock. U.S. refiners reprocess it—degumming, neutralizing, bleaching, and filtering—before hydrotreating. Domestic UCO often reaches processors cleaner and more consistent because it moves through shorter, regulated chains with direct contracts, which also simplifies audits. These differences in chain length and oversight underpin traceability and fraud concerns around some foreign cargoes.

Globally, there’s a growing body of evidence, reporting, and investigative pressure pointing to suspicions and alleged instances of fraud or adulteration in Chinese (and other Asian) UCO exports. 

Transport & Environment’s briefing “Used Cooking Oil: The Certified Unknown” argues that chemically, waste cooking oil and refined virgin vegetable oils can be extremely similar, making lab tests only weakly diagnostic. Audit trails, documentation, and chain-of-custody are often the only reliable check. Because of that, the system relies heavily on paperwork audits rather than full lab confirmation, giving bad actors room to mislabel or mask origin.

Another Transport & Environment’s analysis shows that in many countries (especially in Asia), reported export volumes of UCO exceed credible collection estimates—suggesting some of the exported material must come from sources outside legitimate waste oil streams. Take into consideration Chinese SAF plants already absorb substantial volumes of UCO domestically—with 100,000 to 120,000 tons of UCO being used each month in China’s own biofuel / SAF productions.

The Transport & Environment report cites multiple cases in Europe where imported biodiesel or waste-oil-based fuels were reviewed and found to be based on mislabelled feedstocks. The same report notes that Europe historically identified hundreds of suspicious shipments from China, prompting tightened customs scrutiny and rejections of some imports.

While the evidence is not uniformly definitive, it’s strong enough to be taken seriously by U.S. regulators, senators, and biofuel companies. 

In June 2024, a bipartisan group of farm-state senators sent a letter to the EPA, USDA, U.S. Trade Representative, and Customs, asking for stronger enforcement and transparency around rising UCO imports from China and other countries, citing fraud and mislabeling risks.

More recently, Senator Joni Ernst (R-Iowa) joined calls for the EPA to finalize rules on RINs for imported biofuels and to hold firm on biomass-based diesel volume mandates, with emphasis on protecting domestic agriculture. Senators have also urged the EPA to finalize the “Set 2” RFS rule with strong biomass-based diesel targets and provisions that favor domestic feedstocks.

Even as Congress and the agencies press reform, legal and practical challenges remain—for instance, refining complex rules distinguishing domestic vs. imported feedstocks without violating WTO or trade obligations.

Because domestic collection capacity and feedstock availability lag demand, overly aggressive restrictions on imports could strain supply or raise fuel costs. Enforcement of traceability rules for imports demands substantial audit, testing, and verification infrastructure, which is still evolving.

Continuing to import waste oils keeps renewable diesel and SAF capacity fully utilized at attractive short-run costs, but it perpetuates strategic dependence and traceability disputes. Investing to expand domestic collection and pre-treatment—especially across the Southeast, urban Midwest, and institutional generators—builds a cleaner, verifiable, home-grown feedstock base that supports the agricultural economy, reduces lifecycle emissions, and hardens the supply chain against geopolitical shocks. The technology is proven, the companies exist, the credit frameworks are in place, and the untapped supply is real. What remains is scaling domestic infrastructure to match America’s ambition in low-carbon fuels. Additional aggregation hubs, standardized containers and routing, more pre-treatment capacity, and modern traceability tools could unlock significant volumes. Policy that specifically rewards U.S.-sourced waste oil—alongside grants or financing for new pre-treat units—would accelerate that build-out.

    "title": "From restaurant kitchens to commercial jets: The greasy trail of used cooking oil",
    "content": "Accessibility statementSkip to main content

Democracy Dies in Darkness

Climate Solutions

From restaurant kitchens to commercial jets: The greasy trail of used cooking oil

(Scott Suchman; food styling by Lisa Cherkasky/Both for The Washington Post) 

By Nicolás Rivero

September 29, 2025

9 min

Le Diplomate had an emergency. After a week of frying frites, the kitchen at Washington’s famous standby for French cuisine was full to bursting with used grease.

Two waist-high storage tanks in the back of the restaurant sloshed to the brim with dark, viscous oil. During the weekend rush, the staff stored some of the spent grease in plastic tubs, but they were quickly running out of places to put it.

Restaurants are prohibited from dumping grease down the drain because it would clog city sewers. So on a Tuesday afternoon, James Howell nimbly backed his truck into an alley behind Le Diplomate. He hopped down from the cab and snaked a rubber hose to the kitchen. Then with the flip of a switch and a loud drone, the hose slurped the used cooking oil into the truck’s gleaming steel 2,200-gallon tank.

James Howell of Mahoney Environmental collects used cooking oil behind Duke’s Grocery in Washington. (Matt McClain/The Washington Post)

Three bottles — with raw oil on the left, half-processed produce in the middle and refined aviation fuel on the right — in the Neste laboratory in Rotterdam. (Ilvy Njiokiktjien/For The Washington Post)

The spent grease that restaurants unload as waste has become a valuable commodity. If you’ve been on a plane lately, there’s a chance that used cooking oil has helped launch you into the sky. Refineries recycle waste oil into kerosene pure enough to power a Boeing 777\. The process is expensive — but it can create 70 to 80 percent less planet-warming pollution than making jet fuel out of crude oil, experts say.

Last year, airlines burned 340 million gallons of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) — nearly all of it made from used cooking oil or animal fat left over from meat packaging.

 Climate Leap

A series examining innovative and impactful approaches to addressing waste.

PreviousNext

That’s a drop in the bucket compared with the 114 billion gallons of fuel airlines burned overall, which create 2.5 percent of humanity’s carbon pollution, according to the International Energy Agency. But airlines have vowed to use much more SAF to lower their greenhouse emissions. European regulators have set strict rules requiring airlines to use more SAF over time, while U.S. regulators dole out tax credits to coax companies into buying it.

This is the airlines’ main plan for dealing with their greenhouse emissions. Upgrading new planes with more efficient engines helps a little. And, one day, planes may run on electric batteries or hydrogen fuel cells — but those are still decades away and may never work for long flights. To manage most of their climate impact for the foreseeable future, airlines are betting everything on alternative fuels.

Story continues below advertisement

Advertisement

“Ninety-eight percent of \[our greenhouse emissions\] come from the fuel we burn,” said Lauren Riley, chief sustainability officer at United Airlines. “We’ll continue to look everywhere we can around technology and innovation of the aircraft itself and the engine, but we have to look at replacing our fuel.”

Experts say this plan can work, but it will require fuel refiners to dramatically raise SAF production and find new raw materials besides old cooking oil to turn into kerosene. Depending on what they use and how they refine it, this new class of fuel could make flying more sustainable or cause a whole new set of environmental headaches.

Howell, of Mahoney Environmental, collects used cooking oil in Washington. (Matt McClain/The Washington Post)

Harvesting the world’s grease

On his rounds one day in early May, Howell made about two dozen stops at commercial kitchens around Washington, including an upscale cafe in the Michelin Guide, an assisted-living facility, a soul food spot where old chicken bones clogged the hose and an Italian restaurant where two unfortunate rats had drowned in a grease bin while diving for a wayward meatball. By midafternoon, his truck had about 1,200 gallons of grease in its belly.

The company he works for, Mahoney Environmental, pays a few cents a gallon forthe waste fat it collects from 90,000 businesses in the United States. Hundreds of companies gather grease around the globe — with an especially large haul in Southeast Asia, where densely packed restaurants serve up so much fried food that they’ve become the waste oil equivalent of Saudi Arabia’s rich petroleum fields.

Waste oil from kitchens and animal tallow left over from meatpacking plants used to be recycledinto livestock feed. But now, they are mostly turned into fuel: Fat molecules hold a lot of energy, and they are relatively easy to rearrange into diesel and kerosene.

Turning fat into fuel keeps grease out of the landfill and petroleum in the ground. The demand, though, has begun to outstrip the supply.

“There’s only so many waste oils to go around, and … you can’t really squeeze out much more,” said Nikita Pavlenko, who leads the aviation and fuels team at the nonprofit International Council on Clean Transportation. “People aren’t going to be frying more food or processing more cattle to get waste tallow to make fuel. You’re kind of stuck with what you have.”

A hose is deployed to suck used cooking oil into the tank of a collection truck. (Matt McClain/The Washington Post)

Storage tanks for the feedstock (oil or tallow) at Neste in Rotterdam. (Ilvy Njiokiktjien/For The Washington Post)

As regulators push companies to buy and make more fuel from fat, the price of grease has been rising, along with the crime surrounding it.

Thieves sometimes steal grease from collection bins and sell it themselves. Once, Howell said, he stopped at a restaurant only to find an empty bin and a confused cook, who told him an unmarked van had come by earlier and siphoned off their oil.

Grease fraud is a problem, too. In some areas, used cooking oil sells for more than new cooking oil, prompting hucksters to sell virgin oil — including palm oil, which is associated with deforestation in Southeast Asia — as if it were used. It’s hard to catch, since fresh oil spiked with a little restaurant grease is almost indistinguishable from the real thing.

Story continues below advertisement

Advertisement

“You’re potentially paying a premium for something that is worse than fossil fuel,” Pavlenko said.

Fuel companies crack down on fraud by hiring inspectors to go out and check that their grease suppliers really are pumping their product out of deep fat fryers. On his route, Howell takes pictures of every bin before and after he drains it and uploads the proof to a Mahoney Environmental app that verifies where his oil came from.

At the end of the day, Howell unloads his truck at a depot, where the oil is filtered to remove water, flour, spices and any other floating food chunks.

Laboratory Analyst Diederik Schuitemaker in the laboratory at Neste. Neste produces sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), with a key presence in the Netherlands at its Rotterdam refinery. (Ilvy Njiokiktjien/For The Washington Post)

 Turning fat into fuel

Used grease is a global commodity. Once it’s collected, tanker ships and pipelines carry it to fuel refineries around the world — much as they do for crude oil.

Grease ships arrive a couple of times a week at a refinery in Rotterdam run by Neste, the world’s top producer of sustainable jet fuel.

How grease is turned into jet fuel

The ships pump their greasy cargo into insulated holding tanks heated to 140 degrees to keep the fats and oils liquid so they will flow easily through the pipes.

Neste uses a type of clay called bleaching earth to strip out chemicals it doesn’t want — sodium left over from salty foods, phosphorus and various metals.

Then it introduces a catalyst to knock out the oxygen molecules, which would otherwise bond with hydrogen when burned and create moisture that could damage engines.

The process creates a mixture of kerosene, diesel, propane and a plastic precursor called naphtha.

Jet fuel goes through one last step to keep it from freezing midflight in minus-40-degree air. Its straight hydrocarbon chains are bent into spiky, irregular branches that won’t stack up and lump themselves into a solid, even at very low temperatures.

The ships pump their greasy cargo into insulated holding tanks heated to 140 degrees to keep the fats and oils liquid so they will flow easily through the pipes.

Neste uses a type of clay called bleaching earth to strip out chemicals it doesn’t want — sodium left over from salty foods, phosphorus and various metals.

Then it introduces a catalyst to knock out the oxygen molecules, which would otherwise bond with hydrogen when burned and create moisture that could damage engines.

The process creates a mixture of kerosene, diesel, propane and a plastic precursor called naphtha.

Jet fuel goes through one last step to keep it from freezing midflight in minus-40-degree air. Its straight hydrocarbon chains are bent into spiky, irregular branches that won’t stack up and lump themselves into a solid, even at very low temperatures.

Then it introduces a catalyst to knock out the oxygen molecules, which would otherwise bond with hydrogen when burned and create moisture that could damage engines.

The process creates a mixture of kerosene, diesel, propane and a plastic precursor called naphtha.

The Neste facility, located in Europe’s largest port, is ramping up production of SAF made from used cooking oil. (Ilvy Njiokiktjien/For The Washington Post)

Fueling the appetite for sustainable fuel

In 2023, a Boeing 777 flew across the Atlantic Ocean burning fuel made from nothing but waste fat and sugar. The flight was a first, but it was really a publicity stunt — carrying Virgin Atlantic bigwigs, not paying passengers. The fuel is too expensive, and too scarce, for that to make business sense.

Instead, Neste blends its french fry fuel with standard kerosene made from crude oil before delivering it to airports.

SAF is almost identical to standard jet fuel, and it releases just as much CO2 when it’s burned. But experts say there’s a key difference: Drilling for oil takes carbon that was locked away underground and releases it into the atmosphere. Making fuel from used cooking oil and tallow takes carbon that was already circulating through the air and the bodies of plants and animals and recycles it. No new carbon moves from underground storage into the atmosphere.

Sample vials at Neste. (Ilvy Njiokiktjien/For The Washington Post)

Site director Hanna van Luijk at Neste. (Ilvy Njiokiktjien/For The Washington Post)

It takes energy to collect and transport used cooking oil, rearrange fat molecules into jet fuel and get that fuel to planes. But, overall, making and burning SAF adds as much as 80 percent less carbon to the atmosphere as making and burning fossil fuel from crude oil.

Because there isn’t enough waste oil in the world to satisfy the airline industry’s thirst, companies are developing other ways to make low-carbon jet fuel. One option is to grow more crops like soy that can be crushed for oil and turned into jet fuel — although that raises the risk that more land will be cleared for farming in fragile ecosystems like the Brazilian Amazon. Environmentalists have raised similar concerns about raising more corn, sugar cane or beets to create ethanol and convert it into kerosene.

“The problem with crop-based biofuels is it takes land to produce them at a time when we’re already expanding cropland … which means more deforestation, and the carbon losses are far greater than the potential savings from reducing fossil fuel use,” said Tim Searchinger, a senior research scholar at Princeton’s Center for Policy Research on Energy and the Environment.

Story continues below advertisement

Advertisement

Alternately, farmers could grow more cover crops on their fields between their regular planting seasons, which would create a new source of plant oils or ethanol without using extra land. Some companies have experimented with turning trash into jet fuel, but the most prominent player went bankrupt last year. Others are splitting water molecules to harvest their hydrogen and combining it with captured carbon to make fuel.

Experts say it will take a combination of all these methods to make enough green fuel to power the world’s planes.

Howell, of Mahoney Environmental, collects used cooking oil behind Umai Nori. (Matt McClain/The Washington Post)

The one thing all alternative fuel recipes have in common is that they are more expensive than fossil fuel — and experts say they always will be. Making SAF from waste oil is “locked in at a cost which is about two times the cost of fossil jet, and it’s going to be entirely reliant on subsidies,” according to Pavlenko. The other methods could be even more expensive, even after they’ve had time to raise production and lower costs.

The future of the industry will depend on whether the United States keeps tax credits in place and the European Union stands by its green fuel mandates. Neste is expanding its Rotterdam refinery in anticipation of stricter E.U. blending rules, and in the United States, the first large-scale SAF operations started pumping out fuel in recent years in response to new tax credits that have since been weakened.

Back at Le Diplomate, amid the evening dinner rush, frites flow out of the kitchen to feed hungry diners who are unwittingly helping launch planes into the sky with every bite.

In a previous version of this article, a photo caption gave an incorrect name and title of a man working in the laboratory at Neste. He was Diederik Schuitemaker, a laboratory analyst, not Jeroen van der Heijden, a lab shift supervisor.

Used cooking oil (UCO) price forecast: a cornerstone feedstock for sustainable aviation fuel 

 Used Cooking Oil (UCO) has become a vital feedstock for biofuels, particularly Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF), but surging demand, globalized supply chains, and geopolitical risks highlight the need for strategic planning to address supply gaps and sustain production. 

 June 23, 2025 

By Joao Morciani 

 Agriculture Agriculture;Energy transition Biofuels Decarbonization Sustainable fuels Used cooking oil 

Used Cooking Oil (UCO) has rapidly emerged as a critical feedstock for biofuels, especially as Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) becomes the primary growth driver for the biofuels market over the coming years. Both US and European biofuel policies increasingly favor non-food-based feedstocks, positioning UCO prominently within efforts to reduce fuel-pool carbon intensity and dependency on agricultural commodities. 

The UCO supply chain begins locally at restaurants, hotels, and food processors, where specialized recyclers collect and transport waste oil to facilities that clean and refine it into SAF and other biofuels. Yet, surging SAF demand has reshaped global supply flows: the United States, once a net exporter, became a net importer of UCO after 2021 to meet rising domestic consumption driven by aviation-sector sustainability targets.

As supply chains globalize, American SAF producers have increasingly relied on international sources, notably China, to bridge emerging feedstock gaps. However, this dependency amplifies exposure to geopolitical risks, notably disruptions due to escalating trade tensions. The ongoing US-China trade war, along with policy frictions such as the early-2025 imposition of a 10% tariff on Canadian biofuels (excluding SAF), has rattled investor confidence and highlighted the vulnerability of cross-border UCO flows. These uncertainties underline the critical importance of accurate forecasting and strategic planning to mitigate supply risks and sustain stable feedstock access for SAF production.

In June 2025, the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) introduced a final rule that will reduce RIN (Renewable Identification Number) generation for biofuels produced with imported feedstocks as of October 1, 2025\. This rule marks a turning point for the SAF and renewable diesel industries, reshaping sourcing strategies, cost structures, and investment priorities.

For those trading in the biofuels and feedstocks market, we capture pricing across the complex marketplace, including biodiesel, glycerin, renewable identification numbers (RINs), California’s Low-Carbon Fuel Standard (LCFS) credits and related certificate markets in Europe. Learn more.

Demand–supply dynamics

Strong policy support for biofuels derived from low-carbon feedstocks has substantially elevated UCO’s strategic value. Policies promoting renewable fuels increasingly emphasize feedstocks with lower carbon intensity profiles over traditional, food-based oils. Consequently, US demand for UCO has soared, driven by policies incentivizing renewable diesel and other biofuel production. Fastmarkets estimates total UCO usage in the US in 2024 at 8.4 billion pounds, an increase of 42% over the year, underscoring the importance of supportive regulatory frameworks in accelerating demand for sustainable feedstocks.

However, UCO collection infrastructure struggles to match soaring demand. Fastmarkets estimates UCO collection to be at 3.3 billion pounds in 2024, which is insufficient to meet the US biofuel industry’s demand for 5.7 billion pounds of feedstock in the year. The Biden Administration’s ambitious SAF targets of 3 billion gallons by 2030 amplify concerns about potential feedstock shortages.

China has become the dominant supplier of US UCO for biofuel production. In 2024, the US imported approximately 2.8 billion pounds of UCO from China, making it by far the most significant external source of this key low-carbon feedstock. This dependence exposes the US biofuels sector to significant geopolitical risk. Trade tensions, such as the imposition of high US tariffs on Chinese UCO, or broader diplomatic frictions, could abruptly disrupt supply flows.

Additionally, early-2025 guidance on Section 45Z (the Clean Fuel Production Credit) disqualified imported feedstocks—including Chinese UCO—from generating tax credits under the program. With UCO imports ineligible for 45Z credits, the incentive to source foreign oils weakened, contributing to a sharp plunge in US import volumes in April 2025.

Replacing China as a supplier is not a simple task. While countries like Canada, Malaysia, and members of the European Union also export UCO to the US, the scale is significantly smaller. In 2024, Canada exported around 613 million pounds, while all EU member states combined accounted for just over 440 million pounds. Malaysia and the United Kingdom contributed 335 million and 221 million pounds, respectively. These figures pale in comparison to China’s 2.8 billion pounds. Building alternative supply chains of this magnitude would require years of investment in UCO collection infrastructure and trade logistics. With limited global availability and rising demand, few suppliers can match China’s volume and cost efficiency in the near term, putting other low-ci feedstocks on the table as substitutes. Replacing Chinese UCO in the context of the current Trade War depends not only on UCO availability, but also the suppliers’ diplomatic relations with the US.

Among low-carbon-intensity feedstocks, UCO stands out as the only one with significant potential for scalable supply growth. Unlike tallow or other animal fats, which are byproducts limited by livestock production and thus structurally constrained, no one raises cattle to produce tallow; its availability is capped by meat demand. In contrast, UCO production is a function of how much UCO collecting infrastructure there is\[MC1\] .

Global UCO supply is expected to grow in the following years, fueled by strong policy incentives and increasing demand from SAF and renewable diesel producers. This growth is expected to come from improved collection efficiency, the formalization of previously untapped sources, and investments by biofuel producers integrating upstream into the waste oil value chain. Companies like Neste have already moved to secure feedstock through acquisitions and partnerships with collectors, recognizing UCO’s central role in SAF economics.

Still, even with ambitious growth projections, global UCO volumes may fall short of meeting total biofuel demand. That’s why stakeholders must treat UCO as both a strategic opportunity and a bottleneck risk, optimizing its use while developing complementary feedstocks. The coming years will favor players who move early to secure scalable low-CI feedstock supply, and UCO is the most viable path forward in that race.

 UCO price dynamics and forecast

Fastmarkets’ price assessment of UCO in the US Gulf has shown a strong upward trend since 2020, reflecting tightening supply and rising demand from renewable fuel producers. In early 2020, prices hovered in the mid-20 cents per pound range. By late 2022, they had moved into the mid-30s, and by the end of 2023, prices consistently reached the 40s. In 2024, this trend accelerated further, with prices climbing above 50 cents per pound by the end of the year and remaining elevated through early 2025\. This sustained price strength highlights the combination of expanding SAF production capacity, robust policy incentives for low-carbon fuels, and limited availability of alternative low-CI feedstocks.

Volatility was a defining feature of the UCO market in both 2024 and early 2025\. Monthly spreads between the highest and lowest reported prices regularly exceeded 8 cents per pound, with some months approaching a 14-cent range. These sharp swings reflect a market that is highly sensitive to shifts in policy, trade disruptions, and speculative movements. In 2024, for instance, fluctuations in Chinese export volumes, investigations into UCO origin verification\[MC2\] , and shifting expectations around SAF tax credits all contributed to abrupt pricing changes. In 2025, the continuation of this volatility has been fueled by ongoing uncertainty about the future of biofuel policy in the US, including the potential revision of SAF tax credits\[MC3\] , and geopolitical friction affecting UCO trade flows.

Looking ahead, Fastmarkets forecasts prices for the rest of 2025 to remain in the low to mid-50s cents per pound range\[MC4\] , with a brief dip projected mid-year before a gradual recovery into early 2026\. However, these forecasts are highly sensitive to policy direction and trade conditions. If the proposed changes to the 45Z credit are approved, allowing crop-based oilseed feedstocks to generate credits on par with low-CI alternatives, it could significantly reduce demand for low-CI feedstocks in the US, potentially putting downward pressure on UCO prices in the coming year.

In this context, price volatility is likely to persist, and stakeholders across the SAF value chain will need to closely monitor political developments and maintain flexible procurement and pricing strategies to manage feedstock risk effectively.

UCO global market outlook and strategic implications

The evolving policy environment, industry commitments to decarbonization, and competition for feedstocks are reshaping the UCO market landscape. Government mandates and sustainability targets have effectively created a stable demand floor for UCO-based renewable fuels. However, inherent limits on UCO availability mean that the market faces structural constraints, necessitating strategic diversification of feedstocks and intensified investment in alternative technologies.

SAF producers and aviation stakeholders must increasingly treat UCO as a strategic resource, securing stable supplies through long-term agreements, vertical integration, and partnerships. They should also engage proactively with policy development to foster supportive frameworks. Additionally, exploring complementary feedstocks and innovative technologies will be essential for long-term viability.

 Conclusion

UCO has transitioned from a simple waste byproduct to a critical component of the aviation sector’s decarbonization efforts. The next few years will further highlight the strategic importance and inherent challenges of relying on UCO. Supply constraints, logistical complexities, price volatility, and evolving sustainability standards are significant factors that industry stakeholders must manage effectively.

Accurate forecasting and strategic planning will be crucial for navigating this complex landscape. Fastmarkets’ market insights and price forecasts offer essential tools for stakeholders, providing clarity on emerging supply bottlenecks, pricing trends, and regulatory impacts. Utilizing such data enables airlines and biofuel producers to make informed procurement and investment decisions, optimizing their strategies to secure cost-effective and sustainable SAF supplies.

Given these dynamics, stakeholders should actively leverage comprehensive market intelligence and strategic foresight to ensure a robust and resilient SAF supply chain. UCO’s central role in the aviation industry’s sustainability journey underscores the need for careful resource management, proactive risk mitigation, and strategic innovation to maintain momentum toward a cleaner aviation future.

Unlocking the potential of waste oils

In the race toward a sustainable energy future, renewable diesel and sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) are emerging as pivotal biofuels. 
These fuels, derived from hydrogenated oils and fats, known as HVO (Hydrotreated Vegetable Oil) and HEFA (Hydroprocessed Esters and Fatty Acids), offer a cleaner alternative to traditional fossil fuels. 
However, with the potential of these renewable fuels comes the challenge of refining impure feedstocks, particularly when waste materials are involved. 
This is where BDI-BioEnergy International steps in, leveraging its expertise in waste oil processing to make sustainable fuels more viable and efficient than ever before. 
By addressing the intricate needs of waste-based oils and fats, BDI is paving the way for cleaner energy and a more sustainable fuel economy. 

The importance of advanced pretreatment 

Producing biofuels from waste oils is not as simple as refining fossil fuels. Waste oils, whether from used cooking oil or animal fats, contain impurities that can disrupt downstream processing steps.

Experimental investigation on a diesel engine using waste cooking oil biodiesel-alcohol-diesel ternary blends with Al2O3 nanoparticles

Mark Sudarsanam1,
Jayaraman Jayaprabakar2,
Yarrapragada K. S. S. Rao3,
Harish Venu4,
Arunkumar Thirugnanasambandam5,
Anil Singh Yadav6,
Tabish Alam7,
Abhishek Sharma8 &
…
Alok Kumar Ansu9
Show authors 

Scientific Reports volume 15, Article number: 42979 (2025)Cite this article 

1035 Accesses
Metrics details

 Subjects

Chemistry
Energy science and technology
Engineering
Materials science

Abstract

The aim of this study is to examine the synergistic effect of a ternary blend of waste cooking oil biodiesel, pentanol, and diesel, combined with the catalytic activity of Al2O3 nanoparticles in a direct injection (DI) diesel engine. While extensive research has been conducted on binary fuel blends (e.g., biodiesel-diesel), studies exploring the combined effect of three fuels i.e. biodiesel (from waste cooking oil), a higher alcohol (pentanol), and diesel is less common. This study investigates the potential benefits of using this specific combination in a diesel engine, with the goal of improving combustion and reducing emissions. A key focus of the study is identifying the optimal concentration of Al2O3 nanoparticles to achieve maximum performance and emission reduction in the ternary blend. All experimental procedures were carried out in accordance with ASTM standards. Biodiesel was produced through the transesterification process, and the sample blends were prepared accordingly. The fuel properties of the blends were found to be within the recommended limits. The samples were evaluated in a 4-stroke, constant-speed, DI diesel engine. An optimization analysis of the experimental results was performed using Taguchi/Grey relational analysis to determine the best combination of blend ratios and operating conditions. The most effective combination for butanol-based ternary blends was Bu10B30D60 with 50 ppm of nano-additive at 50% engine load. Similarly, for pentanol-based ternary blends (Pe10B30D60), the optimal condition was with 50 ppm of nano-additive at 100% load, while for propanol-based blends (Pr10B30D60), the optimal condition was at 0% load with the same nanoparticle concentration. According to the findings, ternary blends containing pentanol and waste cooking oil biodiesel demonstrated significantly better performance and lower emissions compared to the other blends.

 Introduction

Current compression ignition (CI) engines operate on liquid fuels, which are primarily derived from crude oil. Crude oil is refined to produce diesel, a commonly used liquid fuel. However, due to the growing demand for fossil fuels, the depletion of oil reserves, and increasingly stringent pollution regulations, researchers are showing increased interest in alternative fuels. One such alternative is biodiesel, which is produced from plant and animal fats. Biodiesel consists of long-chain alkyl esters derived from these fats. It is commonly produced through a process known as transesterification, in which vegetable oils or animal fats chemically react with an alcohol to produce biodiesel. When methanol is used as the alcohol, the resulting product is fatty acid methyl esters (FAME) the most common form of biodiesel. Although ethanol can also be used, methanol is preferred due to its lower cost.

Biodiesel can be made from both edible and non-edible plant oils such as soybean oil1."), jatropha oil2 and Tyre Pyrolysis Oil (TPO) blends. Fuel 108, 699–708. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.fuel.2012.12.042

 (2013)."),3."), rubber seed oil4, palm oil5."), mango seed oil6."), mahua oil7."),8."), cottonseed oil9."), lignocellulosic materials10."), canola oil11."), linseed oil12."), algae oil13."), industrial waste oil14."), corn oil15."), olive oil 16."), wheat starch17."), and cassava18."). Numerous studies have already been conducted on the performance of biodiesel derived from these sources. In addition to being a viable fuel for CI engines, biodiesel is also a low-carbon substitute for heating oil. It offers several advantages, including higher cetane numbers and excellent lubricity, which helps extend the lifespan of high-pressure diesel injection systems and reduces wear in the fuel system. Biodiesel contains no sulfur and is often blended with ultra-low sulfur diesel to enhance lubricity. Biodiesel is biodegradable and emits fewer pollutants without releasing toxic substances. Biodiesel blends can be used in existing CI engines with little or no modification. As the volumetric concentration of biodiesel increases, Sauter mean diameter (SMD) values also rise. These values are directly influenced by the thermophysical properties of the fuel 19."). Because biodiesel has higher viscosity and surface tension than conventional diesel, biodiesel-diesel blends exhibit larger SMD values. Nevertheless, the fuel spray penetration of these blends remains comparable to that of pure diesel20.").

Waste cooking oils (WCOs) are advantageous second-generation biodiesel feedstocks that can be utilized as a sustainable energy source21."). The staggering volume of WCOs generated worldwide has led to significant societal, economic, and environmental concerns. It is estimated that approximately 15 million tonnes of WCOs are produced globally each year22."),23. A large portion of WCOs consists of triglycerides, monoglycerides, and diglycerides. Additionally, free fatty acids (FFAs) are present, typically ranging from 5 to 20% by weight. Triglycerides, composed of both unsaturated and saturated fatty acids, are commonly used as base chemicals in various industries to produce high-value products24.").

Biodiesel derived from waste cooking oil is currently being explored as an attractive alternative fuel due to its low emissions, biodegradability, non-toxic nature, and near-zero carbon footprint25."). In recent years, this type of biodiesel has gained significant popularity. However, there are certain drawbacks associated with the long-term use of WCO biodiesel, including reduced thermal efficiency, carbon deposits on valves, and scuffing of piston rings in engines26 doped with alumina nano-additives. Sci Rep 2024;14:16228."). One of the most important concerns is the stability of biodiesel, especially when produced from used cooking oil. A major issue is the high viscosity of WCO biodiesel, which negatively affects atomization and pumping properties when used in CI engines. To mitigate these disadvantages, the viscosity of clean biodiesel should be reduced as much as possible. One study found that using zinc oxide nanoparticles combined with tungsten phosphoric acid as a catalyst can reduce peroxide levels and increase the stability of used cooking oil biodiesel blends27."). This type of solid acid catalyst (SAC) used in the transesterification process also has a minor influence on fuel properties. Additionally, the brake thermal efficiency (BTE) of WCO biodiesel blends was found to be higher than that of conventional diesel blends. Calcium oxide (CaO) nanoparticles, when synthesized and used as additives, also appear to be a promising option for enhancing the combustion properties of engines running on WCO biodiesel blends28.").

However, one disadvantage of using esters is their high viscosity, which leads to various challenges, including cold starting. To address this issue, alcohol fuels such as ethanol and butanol can be added to biodiesel-diesel blends to improve their overall fuel properties. This addition helps increase engine performance and combustion efficiency, while simultaneously reducing harmful pollutants like smoke and particulates29."). Given the growing concerns about alcohol-based biofuels and biodiesel, an alternative and expanded approach to mixing alcohol with both diesel and biodiesel is being actively explored. This strategy may alleviate some of the current concerns associated with biodiesel, as high-alcohol pentanol has been shown to improve fuel quality30."). Owing to the its superior fuel properties, high-alcohol pentanol could potentially mitigate some of the recent challenges faced in biodiesel fuel usage. At lower percentages, alcohols can be blended with diesel fuel. Due to their higher latent heat of vaporization and lower net calorific value, alcohols are commonly used in blends. Additionally, because alcohols promote low-temperature combustion, their incorporation into base gasoline significantly reduces NOx emissions31.").

Lower C-H chain alcohols, such as ethanol and methanol, have been used in several studies as blended fuels; however, this often leads to phase separation and poor ignition characteristics32 mode. Fuel 170, 49–59 (2016)."). Alcohols with longer C-H chains and comparatively higher calorific values, such as butanol, pentanol, and octanol, are potential additives to diesel–biodiesel blends to mitigate these issues. Several studies have shown that adding these higher C-H alcohols to diesel helps reduce CO and NOx emissions. Alcohols with more than 4 carbon atoms (up to 10 carbon atoms) are considered higher alcohols, which are typically more viscous and oily. Alcohols with more than 12 carbon atoms are solid at room temperature. Alcohols such as butanol, pentanol, propanol, and octanol, which have longer C-H chains and higher calorific values, can be added to diesel and biodiesel to reduce emissions and improve fuel economy. However, certain stabilizers are required to homogenize diesel-alcohol and biodiesel-alcohol mixtures. These stabilizers are relatively expensive, which increases the overall fuel cost. To address this, several studies have been conducted to eliminate the need for stabilizers, leading to the development of ternary blends.

When 10–15% biodiesel is added to diesel-alcohol blends, phase stratification is reduced, creating a novel fuel blend known as the ternary fuel blend33."). This approach results in a fuel that is less expensive than conventional diesel. Therefore, a ternary fuel mixture of diesel, alcohol, and biodiesel could serve as a viable alternative fuel for current diesel engines. The use of a ternary mixture of waste cooking oil biodiesel, higher alcohols, and diesel in CI engines has been rarely explored.

Nano-additives are widely used to investigate the effects of biodiesel–diesel blends on ignition delay (ID) and combustion34.") 35."). When nano-additives are added to fuels like gasoline or diesel, they act as viscosity reducers, enhancing combustion activity. Metal oxide nanoparticles can also promote secondary atomization processes, thereby improve thermal efficiency and reduce emissions36."). The combination of biodiesel and nano-additive leads to enhanced combustion quality, which in turn increases the engine’s thermal efficiency. When added to fuel, these metal-based nanoparticles exhibit a natural catalytic effect on hydrocarbon combustion reducing ID and soot ignition temperature while increasing the energy density of the fuel blend. Recently, a variety of nano-additives have been explored to enhance engine performance. However, the optimal concentration of nano-additives required to improve performance and minimize emissions in diesel engines remains unclear37."). Therefore, it is essential to identify the ideal ratio of nano-additives in relation to engine parameters, without compromising performance or emissions. Taguchi method has been recognized as an effective strategy for multi-objective optimization, including engine development. Nonetheless, limited research has explored the effects of blend concentration and nanoparticle dosage as independent variables to achieve optimal engine performance and minimal emissions38 2 and CaO nanostructures. J. Exp. Nanosci. 5, 93–105 (2010).").

Based on insights from the literature, the current research focuses on analyzing the potential use of a ternary blend in a CI engine. This study aims to improve engine performance and reduce emissions by utilizing ternary blends of WCO biodiesel, alcohol, and diesel, supplemented with Al2O3 nanoparticles, as fuel in a direct injection (DI) diesel engine. The primary objective of this research is to examine how these ternary blends, in combination with nanoparticles, influence emissions, combustion characteristics, and engine performance. The study addresses a significant research gap, the lack of comprehensive investigation into the specific combination of alcohol, Al2O3 nanoparticles, and WCO biodiesel in diesel engines. Key contributions of this research include assessing the feasibility of these blends as sustainable alternatives to conventional diesel, and identifying the optimal blend ratios that enhance engine performance while minimizing emissions. This study highlights the potential of WCO biodiesel–alcohol–diesel blends as a competitive and environmentally friendly substitute for fossil diesel. It also provides guidance on ideal blend ratios to improve performance and reduce harmful exhaust emissions. Additionally, the study offers valuable insights into the role of Al2O3 nanoparticles in enhancing combustion and reducing emissions. Ultimately, it underscores the viability of using waste cooking oil as a sustainable feedstock for biodiesel production, thereby supporting circular economy initiatives.

The key merits of this research lie in its focus on sustainability, the exploration of novel fuel blend combinations, and the potential for improved engine performance. While the study specifically investigates a diesel engine, the findings may be applicable to a wide variety of diesel-powered vehicles. However, the study also has certain limitations. Additionally, the research acknowledges that biodiesel blends can lead to increased NOx emissions, highlighting the need for further investigation and the development of effective mitigation strategies. Moreover, long-term studies are necessary to assess the durability and reliability of engines running on these blends. The use of biodiesel can sometimes result in issues such as carbon deposits or piston ring scuffing, which may affect engine longevity. To reduce dependence on fossil fuels, this study demonstrates that WCO biodiesel–alcohol–diesel blends have strong potential as competitive alternatives to conventional diesel fuel. It offers recommendations for optimal blend ratios that enhance engine performance while reducing harmful emissions. Furthermore, the research provides insights into how Al2O3 nanoparticles can further improve combustion efficiency and emissions control. Finally, it emphasizes the potential of using waste cooking oil as a sustainable feedstock for biodiesel production, thereby supporting circular economy initiatives.

Experimental

The methodology adopted for achieving the envisaged objective is presented in Fig. 1. The test rig consists of a four stroke, vertical, single cylinder, air cooled, DI diesel engine which is basically used for stationery applications. It is a kind of engine that can handle wide variety of viscous fuels.

Common rail direct injection (CRDI) is a cutting-edge technique that delivers highly pressured fuel to injectors through a common rail. As the name suggests, it is a direct injection system, meaning that fuel is sprayed straight into the cylinders by the injectors. Some previous results have shown that CRDI technology could combust better with diesel. This engine is attached with sequence of instruments to bring out the results with variable loads from 0 to 100% at intervals of 25%. Figure 2 shows how the experimentation setup is laid out.  Biodiesel production

Cleaned waste cooking oils were collected from the kitchen of Sathyabama Institute of Science and Technology, where the oil is used for frying various food items. Initially, the FFA content of the oil samples was measured, followed by the transesterification process. Sodium hydroxide pellets (caustic soda) were used as a catalyst. Methanol was mixed with dry sodium hydroxide pellets to dissolve them. A solution of 180 ml of methanol and 3.75 g of NaOH pellets was thoroughly stirred for 30 min. This mixture of alcohol and catalyst was then added to the oil in a conical flask. A magnetic stirrer, running at 300 rpm, was used to mix the fluid evenly for two and a half hours at a constant reaction temperature of 60 °C. Initially, the catalyst reacts with the FFA in the oil, forming soap. The presence of water and free fatty acids in the oil can lead to the formation of emulsions with methanol or oil, which may hinder the reaction. These emulsions were discarded. After the reaction was completed and the alcohol was removed, the solution was left to settle for 24 h, allowing the methyl ester and glycerin layers to separate completely. Due to the difference in density, glycerin, being denser, settled at the bottom and was drained off, leaving the methyl esters (biodiesel) as the upper layer. The transesterification process is shown in Fig. 3.

Fig. 3

Transesterified waste cooking oil.

Full size image

The esters are stored after the glycerine has been extracted and they have been washed with warm water to remove the leftover residues. A flask separator was used to extract the methyl esters from sedimentation. The biodiesel was washed with 10% water until it reached the desired purity. Following this, it was dried using a dryer and then placed under an electric fan for 12 h to ensure complete drying. The control factors of the biodiesel production process are presented in Table 2.

Preparation of nano alumina

The solution gelation method, which entailed dissolving the sample of 25 g of aluminium nitrate in the citric acid with 0.5 as the molar ratio, was used to create alumina nanoparticles. With continuous stirring and heated at 80 °C the solution is gelled. After being dried for 10 h at 90 °C, the gel was melted at 1055 °C to produce a white powder as shown in Fig. 4. Figure 5 displays the X-Ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of Al2O3. Diffraction peaks of Al2O3 at 2θ values are 33°, 38°, 52°, 64°, 68°, 78°. It confirmed that the Al2O3 powder has cubic phases and agreed by the file No. 46–1212 of standard JCPDS-ICDD. Table 3 shows the lattice parameters of the produced Al2O3 nano powder particles derived from the XRD pattern39.").

 Blend preparation and fuel properties

The sonicating method is used to combine biodiesel-diesel with alcohol. Hielscher brand ultrasonic mixing reactor was used for blending alchols with biodiesel and diesel. In this investigation, a bioruptor system consisting of a water bath and high-powered ultrasound generators beneath the tank was employed. The Bioruptor and probe sonicator generate ultrasonic radiation at the same frequency (20 kHz). When a metallic bar comes into and touches the sample, it assists to transmit the ultrasonic waves into the tubes. This metallic patented resonance bar reflects ultrasound from the bath, increasing the sonication efficiency. After the biodiesel is mixed with diesel and alcohol, it is placed in the ultrasonicator and agitated for 30 to 45 min to produce a homogeneous blend.

Three types of blends with biodiesel and diesel were prepared from each alcohol. Table 4 gives the acronym and constituents of the prepared blends for this study. The biodiesel samples are tested for fuel properties as per the ASTM standards and shown in Table 5. The characteristics reveal that the manufactured fuel samples fall within the ASTM standards, and these fuels may be used to power a CI engine. All these blends were tested in engine without and with 25ppm and 50ppm of nano additive additions.

 Brake thermal efficiency

The ratio of engine brake power to the heat input is known as its BTE. Fuel characteristics such as density and heating value have significant impact on the BTE. The Figs. 6, 7 and 8 shows the variations of BTE values against the engine load for the D100, Bu20B20D60, Bu15B25D60, Bu10B30D60, Pe20B20D60, Pe15B25D60, Pe10B30D60, Pr20B20D60, Pr15B25D60, Pr10B30D60 without nano particle addition and with 25ppm and 50ppm nano particle additions respectively.

Brake thermal efficiency of the blends without nano additive.

Fig. 7

Brake thermal efficiency of the blends with 50ppm Al2O3.

Full size image

Fig. 8

Brake thermal efficiency of the blends with 25ppm Al2O3.

Full size image

The BTE values in Table 6 demonstrate that; the diesel has greater thermal efficiency values. Its high calorific value is the reason for this. As the biodiesel concentration in the blends increases, so do the BTE curves for the blends. Out of all the higher alcohol ternary lends tested, n-pentanol ternary fuel blends outperformed compared to all other tested blends40."),41."),42."). The mean BTE values of all the blends were increased by 4% when 50ppm of Al2O3 nano additives are added average at all tested loads. The mean BTE value increases by a very less amount of 0.3% when 25ppm of Al2O3 nano additives are added average for all tested loads. It turns out that the performance of blends is not significantly affected by the 25ppm of nano additive addition. This shows out of the three types of blends tested, the 50ppm nano additive added blends show enhanced BTE values for all the blends43."). The BTE values for the diesel and the ternary mixtures increase with increase in engine load and reaches a maximum at 75% load and after that finds a drop. At lower load condition, straight diesel achieved greater efficiency values than the blends at all three injection pressures.

Brake specific energy consumption

Brake specific fuel consumption (BSEC) is known as the amount of fuel utilized per unit power developed per unit time. It primarily depends on the properties of the fuel, particularly its heating value. However, the BSEC is calculated based on the density of the fuel only. For comparing different fuel types with different calorific values, brake specific energy consumption (BSEC) values are appropriate. The Figs. 9, 10 and 11 show the variations of BSEC values against engine load for the straight D100, Bu20B20D60, Bu15B25D60, Bu10B30D60, Pe20B20D60, Pe15B25D60, Pe10B30D60, Pr20B20D60, Pr15B25D60 and Pr10B30D60 without and with 50ppm and 25ppm Al2O3 nano particles. As the biodiesel concentration in the blend is more, the BSEC value for each biofuel mixture increases steadily. Of all the tested blends, the pentanol ternary biodiesel blends Pe20B20D60, Pe15B25D60 and Pe10B30D60 produced less BSEC values44."),[45](/articles/s41598-025-26974-2ref-CR45 "Park, S. H., Cha, J. & Lee, C. S. Impact of biodiesel in bioethanol blended diesel on the engine performance and emissions characteristics in compression ignition engine. Appl. Energy 99, 334–343. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.apenergy.2012.05.050

 (2012)."). The results revealed that BSEC values for all the blends were decreased by 0.35% on average when 50ppm of Al2O3 nano additives at all loads. The average BSEC value decreases by 0.15–0.2% when 25ppm of Al2O3 nano additives are added at all loads. It turns out that the BSEC value of the blends is not significantly affected by the addition of nano additive addition. It also revealed that, the 50ppm nano additive added blends show favorable BSEC values for all the blends46.").

Effect of load: The energy consumption is decreased with increase in engine load for all the tested blends. At higher loads of the engine, the energy consumed is almost the same for all the blend types. At lower loads, always more fuel is consumed with or without nano-additive additions. The full load condition of the engine decreased the BSEC values by at least 20% on average for all the fuel types, either with nano additives or without.

Exhaust gas temperature

One of the output factors that quantifies how much heat is lost is the engine’s exhaust gas temperature (EGT). The EGT values of D100, Bu20B20D60, Bu15B25D60, Bu10B30D60, Pe20B20D60, Pe15B25D60, Pe10B30D60, Pr20B20D60, Pr15B25D60 and Pr10B30D60 without and with 50ppm and 25ppm Al2O3 nano particles are depicted in Figs. 12, 13 and 14 respectively.

Fig. 12

Exhaust Gas Temperature of the blends without nano additive.

Full size image

Fig. 13

Exhaust Gas Temperature of the blends with 50ppm of Al2O3.

Full size image

Fig. 14

Exhaust Gas Temperature of blends with 25ppm of Al2O3.

Full size image

Under all circumstances, blends of biofuel have produced higher EGT values than pure diesel. If the biodiesel concentration in the blend rose, the EGT value for each biofuel blend decrease steadily. On comparing the blends, pentanol ternary biodiesel blends Pe20B20D60, Pe15B25D60 and Pe10B30D60 produced lesser EGT values followed by butanol ternary biofuel blends. The results revealed that nano additive definitely boosted the EGT values. The EGT values for all the blends were increased by 5 to 6% on average when 50ppm of Al2O3 nano additives at all loads. The average EGT value increases approximately by 1.5% when 25ppm of Al2O3 nano additives are added at all loads. It turns out that the EGT value is affected slightly by the inclusion of nano additive addition. nano additive added blends would have increased the combustion temperature in turn results increase in EGT for all the blends. High cylinder temperature during the combustion causes more heat transfer from the cylinder walls which in turn rises the EGT values. As the load increases, the EGT values for both diesel and biodiesel blend raised. The full load state in this study showed greater EGT values for all blends because larger loads result in higher combustion temperatures. As the load rises, extra fuel is pumped into the cylinder, raising the EGT to maintain the same power output. The fuel’s oxygen concentration enhances combustion, raising the EGT. The increased ID and intrinsic oxygen content are the causes of the greater combustion temperature.

 Heat release rate

Heat release rate (HRR) is known as the amount of heat spawned during combustion in the engine cylinder. This heat is utilized for shaft work and to heat the working medium, increasing its internal energy. Some portion of the heat is lost with the cooling water through cylinder walls as well as cylinder heads. The Figs. 15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22, 23 shows the variations of heat release rate in kJ/m3deg against crank angle (°CA) for Diesel, Bu20B20D60, Bu15B25D60, Bu10B30D60, Pe20B20D60, Pe15B25D60, Pe10B30D60, Pr20B20D60, Pr15B25D60 and Pr10B30D60 without nano additive addition and with 50ppm and 25ppm Al2O3 addition at zero load, half load and full load respectively. The biodiesel blends and pure diesel show rapid premixed combustion trailed by the diffused combustion. Fast burning of the pre-mixed blend, followed by fast heat release and dispersed combustion, occur shortly after the delay time. The combustion rate is determined by the available flammable air–fuel combination. The pre-mixed combustion for the biodiesel blends is extremely quick, according to the study’s heat release rate curves. For pure diesel without nano additive addition, the peak HRR value is 19.9 kJ/m3 occurred at 3°bTDC for zero load condition, 44.12 kJ/m3 occurred at 5°bTDC for half load condition and 40.28 kJ/m3 occurred at 6°bTDC for Full load condition. Nitrogen oxides

Nitrogen oxide (NOX) generation in CI engines is caused by a longer retention period and a higher flame temperature54. Compared to diesel, the biodiesel blends have a higher oxygen content[55](/articles/s41598-025-26974-2ref-CR55 "Sharma, A. & Murugan, S.  (2017)."). This oxygen from the fuel promotes the production of NOX. The pentanol ternary biodiesel blends Pe20B20D60, Pe15B25D60 and Pe10B30D60 produced higher EGT values followed by butanol ternary biofuel blends. When the pressure and temperature is high almost all the injected fuel is burnt which leads to boosting up of peak cylinder temperature which in turn produces more NOX emissions. The trend is reversed for the other blends, i.e. the combustion will take place in power stroke which results in less peak temperature56."). The NOX emissions steadily rise in tandem with the load. The NOX emissions are lower at the initial load circumstances. Greater combustion temperatures brought on by further load increases result in noticeably greater NOX readings57.").

Carbon monoxides

Carbon monoxide (CO) is produced during the transitional phases of the oxidation of fuel. The interaction between the CO and the oxidants in the cylinder causes the oxidation from CO to CO2. The CO won’t be fully oxidized if there are insufficient oxidants, a low gas temperature, or a brief retention period. Carbon monoxide may be produced from extreme mixture ratios. The Figs. 39, 40, 41 show the CO emissions against the engine load for the straight diesel, Bu20B20D60, Bu15B25D60, Bu10B30D60, Pe20B20D60, Pe15B25D60, Pe10B30D60, Pr20B20D60, Pr15B25D60 and Pr10B30D60 without nano additive addition, with 50ppm and 25 ppm Al2O3 nano additive addition at various engine loads, respectively. In comparison to pure diesel, with greater oxygen content, which encourages better oxidation, led to somewhat reduced CO emissions for the blends. However, the biofuel blends Bu20B20D60, Pr20B20D60, and Pr15B25D60 occasionally showed superior CO emissions particularly at lower load conditions. Their poor spray formation properties, which result from the lesser calorific values, are the source of the rise in CO. In contrast, the mixes Pe20B20D60, Pr10B30D60, and Pe10B30D60 generated reduced CO emissions due to their complete combustion and high oxygen concentration in biodiesel.

Smoke opacity

One kind of emission particle that is created when fuels are deposited on the walls of the cylinder is smoke60."). The Figs. 42, 43, 44 show the smoke opacity values against load for the straight diesel, Bu20B20D60, Bu15B25D60, Bu10B30D60, Pe20B20D60, Pe15B25D60, Pe10B30D60, Pr20B20D60, Pr15B25D60 and Pr10B30D60 without nano additive addition, with 50ppm and 25 ppm Al2O3 nano additive addition at various engine loads, respectively. The smoke opacity ratings of the biofuel blends were greater than that of diesel. This is because blends of alcohol and biodiesel have heavy molecules, low volatility, and high viscosity. Because biofuel blends are poorly atomized, it is witnessed that the smoke values rises as the biodiesel concentration rises. Because of their light viscosity, the pentanol ternary blends burn better than their counterparts, resulting in somewhat lower smoke opacity ratings. It is learned that, the 50ppm nano additive addition recorded less the smoke opacity than the 25ppm addition. The complete combustion is realized in pentanol blends because of effective atomization, causing less smoke formation for these fuel types61."). The complete combustion could reduce the smoke formation for all the fuel types62."). The smoke opacity steadily increases as the load does63."). For every fuel type examined, the variations in the blends’ values at lower loads are minimal.

 Unburnt hydrocarbons

Heterogeneous combustion is a feature of CI engine. Fuel evaporation and air–fuel mixing with unburned gases occur at the same time61."). The generation of unburned hydrocarbon (UHC) pollutants from this type of combustion is a complicated topic to examine. The generation of UHC during combustion is caused by very rich and lean mixes64."). Hydrocarbon emission, which quantifies the total amount of unburned hydrocarbon, can be used to demonstrate how complete a combustion process is. Biodiesel with a higher cetane number ignites faster and operates more efficiently, reducing hydrocarbon emissions65."). The slow mixing of ternary blends with air results in an over-rich mixture or quenching of the combustion reaction, and this can result in incomplete combustion products and high UHC in the exhaust gases. Incomplete combustion products and excess UHC in exhaust gases may result from an over-rich mixture or the quenching of the combustion reaction induced by the slow mixing of ternary mixes with air. The Figs. 45, 46, 47 show the HC emissions against load for the Diesel, Bu20B20D60, Bu15B25D60, Bu10B30D60, Pe20B20D60, Pe15B25D60, Pe10B30D60, Pr20B20D60, Pr15B25D60 and Pr10B30D60 without nano additive addition, with 50ppm and 25 ppm Al2O3 nano additive addition at various engine loads, respectively.

When compared to diesel, the biodiesel blends show varying levels of UHC emissions. The ternary blends from butanol and propanol occasionally had higher UHC readings. These biodiesel kinds with higher viscosity and density characteristics have lower UHC emissions. Because of their high oxygen concentration and low viscosity, the pentanol ternary blends have somewhat lower UHC values than the other blends. The blends’ UHC values fall as the amount of biodiesel rises. The UHC emission levels drop when the nano additive level in the blends is increased. By providing adequate space and time for full combustion, the increased injection pressure after adding the nano additives lowers the generation of UHC. Because it takes less time for full combustion for the blends without nano additives, the tendency is reversed. When the load increase, UHC emission also increases for all the tested fuels. But there is no much rise in the UHC emission values from Zero load to Maximum load condition. It demonstrates that load fluctuation has very little effect on the production of UHC. There will be fewer hydrocarbon emissions at higher flame temperatures. Since biodiesel has high oxygen concentration, it combusts more competently and releases less hydrocarbons. In the case of biodiesel mixes, it guarantees full combustion. These findings are consistent with some past studies66,67."). According to some studies, biodiesel alcohol blends greatly reduce UHC emissions and smoke26 doped with alumina nano-additives. Sci Rep 2024;14:16228."). Compared to those studies, the current study uses a higher percentage of alcohol (low cetane number) and biodiesel (increased viscosity), which comprises larger molecules. The evaporation rate slows as the droplet size grows due to the biodiesel’s high viscosity. Higher HC and smoke generation resulted from an increase in ID induced by alcohols’ lower cetane number. A reduced evaporation rate might lead to an over-rich mixture or quench the combustion reaction, resulting in incomplete combustion products, HC, and smoke in the exhaust gases68.").

Grey relational analysis

Several strategies were employed to sort the relationship between multiple variables. One of those is the Grey relational method. The Taguchi method, which is based on Grey relational analysis, can be utilized to address multi-response problems69."),70. This method is used to optimize the concentration of the ternary blend in percentage of volume, the concentration of the Al2O3 nano additive, and the load percentage71."). The Grey relationship coefficients are calculated and the experimental results are standardized. These factors offer the connection between appropriate and actual values. The coefficients were then averaged to define grade values for the three process answers. The overall analysis of the several trial data is originated from the calculated Grey relational grades. The process for calculating the Grey grade relationship value is explained in the phases that follow.

Initially, the S/N ratio (Yij) was calculated from the original experimental data. The parameters brake thermal efficiency and cylinder pressure are set as greater the better-quality attributes since the parameters that result from the output need to be maximized. Equation (1) is used to get the S/N ratios for these values.

$$\\frac{{\\text{S}}}{{\\text{N}}}{\\text{Ratio}} = - 10{\\text{log }}\\left( {\\frac{1}{{\\text{n}}}} \\right)\\mathop \\sum \\limits\_{k = 0}^{n} 1/{\\text{Y}}^{2}$$

 (1)

It is necessary to limit the emission values, brake specific energy, HRR and EGT and to be set as the lower the better values. Equation (2) is used to get the S/N ratios from these values.

$$\\frac{{\\text{S}}}{{\\text{N}}}{\\text{ratio}} = - 10{\\text{log }}\\left( {\\frac{1}{{\\text{n}}}} \\right)\\mathop \\sum \\limits\_{k = 0}^{n} {\\text{y}}^{2}$$

 (2)

Next, the parameters’ normalized values are computed. A normalization is done to scale the single input into an appropriate range and distribute it uniformly. The Eq. (3) is used to calculate these normalized values through transformation.

$$\\text{xi }( (\\text{k})=\\frac{yi \\left(k\\right)+\\text{min}yi (k)}{\\text{maxyi }\\left(\\text{k}\\right)-\\text{minyi }(\\text{k})}\\text{Yi}2$$

 (3)

The normalized lower the better values are calculated by using the Eq. (4)

$$\\text{xi }( (\\text{k})=\\frac{\\text{maxyi}\\left(\\text{k}\\right)-\\text{yi }(\\text{k})}{\\text{maxyi }\\left(\\text{k}\\right)-\\text{minyi }(\\text{k})}$$

 (4)

Eq. (5) was used to calculate the values of the Grey relational coefficients, or GCij. Equation (6) was used to determine the Grey relational grades (Gi) from the averaged Grey relational coefficients

$$\\text{GC} =\\frac{\\Delta \\text{min}+ \\lambda \\Delta max}{\\Delta \\mathit{ij} \\left(\\text{k}\\right)- \\lambda \\Delta max}$$

 (3.5)

$$\\text{Gi}= \\frac{1}{\\text{m}}{\\sum }\_{k=1}^{n}( \\text{GC})$$

 (3.6)

where;

S/N-signal to noise ratio

Yi-engine output parameter

Xi-normalized value

GC-Grey relational coefficient

Gi-Grey relational grade

Min-minimum

Max-maximum

The Experimental values, S/N ratios, Normalized S/N ratios, ∆s, Grey relational coefficients and Grey relational grades of Butanol, pentanol and propanol-based ternary lends are included in the Appendices section after being tallied. The optimal levels of the single-response Grey grade Gi problem are studied through analysis.
The major effects of the butanol blends are shown in Table 8. the Taguchi’s Grey grade relational analysis found the optimum combination for the butanol blends as Bu10B30D60, 50% load, 50 ppm Al2O3 from the experimental values.
The major effects of the butanol blends are shown in Table 9. The optimum combination for the pentanol blends was found as Pe10B30D60, 100% load, 50 ppm Al2O3 from the experimental values.
The major effects of the butanol blends are shown in Table 10. The optimum combination for the propanol blends was found as Pr10B30D60, 0% load, 50 ppm Al2O3 from the experimental values.

 Conclusions

As per the experimental studies made on the diesel engine with the ternary blends of butanol, pentanol and propanol with waste cooking oil biodiesel and straight diesel with and without nano particle addition loading the following conclusions are made:

The addition Al2O3 nano additive concentration 50 ppm with the ternary blends improved the brake thermal efficiency values of 4% average for all the fuels tested. The brake specific energy consumption values for the ternary blends are higher than the straight diesel with or without nano additive addition. The specific energy consumption decrease slightly for all the fuel used when the nano additives are added.
Addition of 50 ppm of Al2O3 nano additives enhanced the heat release rate whereas the heat release rate is lesser when the blends are combusted without nano additives considerably. By comparing the ternary blends, it is clear that pentanol ternary blends had the maximum peak pressures. Due to the higher cetane number of biodiesel compared to diesel, the ignition delay was shorter for all blends.
Compared to straight diesel, the biofuel ternary blends in this study recorded high NOX values since the biodiesel blends contains more oxygen content. The ternary blends recorded slightly less CO emissions due to the rich oxygen content which leads to complete oxidation. All the ternary blends recorded higher smoke opacity values. When biodiesel content increases in the blends the smoke opacity also increased. Butanol and propanol recorded higher UHC values.
As per the optimization study, the optimum combination found for all the alcohol ternary blends

Scope for future work

In summary, future research should focus on tackling the present difficulties of NOx emissions of biodiesel operation and nanoparticle durability, while improving mixture concentration and engine operating conditions to get the most out of this potential renewable fuel combination. Varying engine loads and speeds, Injection timing and pressure, Exhaust Gas Recirculation (EGR) and Combustion chamber geometry are some of the engine operating conditions can be taken for these fuel samples. The research may be expanded to use quaternary biodiesel mixes in a diesel engine with several cylinders. The chemistry of combustion and atomization may be examined using simulation techniques (CFD). It is possible to assess a simulation process for the performance and combustion of ternary and quaternary biofuel blends in a CI engine. Nanoparticles have the ability to wear down the precise tolerances and critical dimensions of injector orifices and pintels, altering spray patterns and injection timing while also influencing emissions and combustion. To avoid issues like settling and agglomeration, the long-term stability of nanoparticle-enhanced biofuels in storage and use must be thoroughly evaluated.

 Data availability

The datasets generated during and/or analyzed during the current study are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request.
