U.S. Renewable Fuel Standard proposal would mean more vegetable oil imports, high costs, and minimal greenhouse gas reductions

December 16, 2025 | By: Andy Navarrete 

In the last 20 years, the U.S. transportation fuel landscape has transformed: electric vehicles emerged as a clear path to zero-emissions road transport while growth in domestic oil production eliminated U.S. dependence on imported oil. Yet the Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS), a 2005 law requiring the use of biofuels in transport, remains stuck in an era when biofuels seemed like the only option to reduce transportation greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and U.S. dependence on foreign oil. The latest proposal from EPA doubles down on this outdated vision. It would raise food and fuel costs for consumers by increasing the amount of biomass-based diesel (BBD) mandated under the program without delivering meaningful GHG emission benefits. 

EPA’s proposal increases renewable volume obligations (RVOs), the mandatory volumes that specify how much biofuel must be supplied. It also halves the compliance value of imported fuel or fuel produced from imported feedstocks by reducing the generation of renewable identification numbers (RINs)—credits used for compliance with renewable fuel blending mandates. For every gallon of biofuel produced from imported feedstock, twice as much fuel must be supplied to meet RFS obligations. Fuels like biodiesel produced from imported used cooking oil now generate half the compliance value of a domestic fuel, such as soy-derived biodiesel.

EPA justifies these changes by emphasizing the economic and energy security benefits of domestic feedstocks. However, overall U.S. consumption of fats and oils for fuel and other purposes such as cooking and animal feed already exceeds total domestic production. Instead of supporting domestic feedstock producers, the proposal would increase U.S. reliance on imported fats and oils.

The figure below shows how growing imports have supported U.S. BBD consumption. In 2019, domestic fat and oil production met 84% of demand. By 2024, this had fallen to 68%. The gap was filled by more imports of vegetable oil, fat oil, and grease. The United States turned from a net exporter of 0.6 million tonnes in 2019 to a net importer of 3.1 million tonnes in 2024.

Figure 1. U.S. fats and oil supplies, 2019 and 2024

EPA’s proposal would only accelerate this trend, increasing reliance on imported fats, oils, and greases rather than wind them down. The next figure compares EPA’s projection of the 2027 BBD volumes needed to meet the current proposal with expected domestic fat and oil production and non-fuel consumption. Our projections assume the full utilization of soybean crushing capacity projected by the industry, representing a best-case scenario for domestic vegetable oil supply.

Figure 2. U.S. fats and oil supply and use in 2027 under current proposal

As illustrated by the figure, U.S. fat and oil imports would dramatically increase under the proposal; net vegetable oil imports are projected to surge by around 5 million tonnes (from 6.1 to 11.0 MMT). Greater demand for vegetable oil will increase its price, likely around 12% based on a previous analysis of the relationship between biodiesel demand and global vegetable oil prices. 

However, a more dramatic price spike is possible. As described in EPA’s Draft Regulatory Impact Assessment, the 2020–2022 vegetable oil price shock that increased global prices from $700 to $1,800 per metric ton was likely caused by biofuel-driven demand and weather-related supply disruptions. The projected 5 million tonne net increase in U.S. vegetable oil imports is equivalent to 6% of the current global vegetable oil trade, creating a risk of short-term price spikes as global oilseed production responds to the additional demand.

According to EPA analysis, this huge increase in BBD consumption will not even meaningfully reduce U.S. GHG emissions, with savings equivalent to less than 1% of road sector emissions at best. One EPA model even suggests that the use of crop-based BBD fuels would increase GHGs. This is perhaps unsurprising, as current growth in vegetable oil production is concentrated in Brazil and Indonesia, where agricultural expansion often relies on high carbon-stock forested land. Indeed, groundbreaking work from Chen et al. has found that that global demand for BBD between 2002 and 2018 drove the conversion of approximately 1.7 million hectares of forest to oil palm. This means continued market-mediated oil crop expansion could very well offset any emissions reductions from additional BBD use in the United States.

Finally, the proposal’s claims of energy security benefits are unconvincing. Will energy security really be improved by replacing a domestic energy source (petroleum) with one we have to import? And while EPA assumes that the United States will remain the preferred destination for BBD feedstocks globally, this isn’t guaranteed. Changing policies in China have dramatically reduced used cooking oil exports to the United States, and sustainable aviation fuel mandates in the European Union and United Kingdom will heighten competition for feedstock.

Overall, EPA projects its current proposal will saddle consumers with $6.8 billion in extra fuel costs and $2.4 billion in higher food prices each year, all without meaningful emissions cuts or improved U.S. energy independence. Twenty years in, we need a wholesale reconsideration of the Renewable Fuel Standard— the inconsistencies of EPA’s proposal show exactly why reform is needed.

Enhancing diesel engine efficiency with waste cooking oil biodiesel and nano additives for sustainable fuel applications

Haiter Lenin Allasi ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-4212-91631,5,
Amala Justus Selvam2,
Mary Vasanthi Soosaimariyan3 &
…
Sujin Jose Arul4
Show authors 

Scientific Reports volume 15, Article number: 31762 (2025)Cite this article 

2743 Accesses
5 Citations
Metrics details

 Subjects

Energy science and technology
Environmental sciences

Abstract

This study investigates the effect of incorporating nano-additives Cerium oxide (CeO2), Zinc oxide (ZnO), and Titanium oxide (TiO2) at 25 ppm concentration into biodiesel derived from waste cooking oil, with the objective of improving diesel engine performance and reducing exhaust emissions. Experiments were carried out on a single-cylinder four-stroke diesel engine under varying load conditions. Among the tested blends, the B20 + TiO2 (25 ppm) mixture exhibited a modest reduction in brake thermal efficiency (2.53%) and a slight increase in brake specific energy consumption (3.80%) compared to diesel fuel. However, significant emission improvements were achieved, with a reduction in CO (23.42%) and HC (24.78%) emissions, accompanied by a decrease in smoke opacity (12.37%). The findings highlight that TiO2 nano-additive biodiesel blends offer a sustainable and environmentally viable alternative to conventional diesel. The study is constrained by its emphasis on a particular mixture of biodiesel and nano additives, perhaps limiting the generalisability to different combinations or concentrations. The study largely assesses engine performance and emissions under a singular operating condition, potentially neglecting differences in performance across varied loads or speeds.

 Introduction

Currently, more than one billion people lack access to reliable energy, which limits socio-economic development and highlights the global demand for sustainable, low-emission fuels as alternatives to fossil energy sources. The scientific scene of today emphasises a great need for inventions including lower emissions and modern technologies meant to eradicate world greenhouse gas emissions. The research findings illustrate a sharp increase in energy-related pollutant emissions projected to reach a peak in the near future. Furthermore, the findings indicate a significant demand for low-emission products and advancements in technology aimed at reducing greenhouse gas pollutant emissions. This event occurred as a result of the increasing anticipation and momentum to swiftly shift towards energy systems that incorporate renewable energy sources. Moreover, a significant gap has emerged between the ongoing discomfort and the oil retail markets, potentially linked to climate and geopolitical uncertainties[1](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR1 "Agarwal, S., Kumari, S., Mudgal, A. & Khan, S. Green synthesized nanoadditives in Jojoba biodiesel-diesel blends: an improvement of engine performance and emission. Renew. Energy. 147, 1836–1844. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.renene.2019.09.139

 (2020)."). By conducting a thorough analysis of quaternary fuel blends, the team is able to ascertain the optimal fuel proportions, the resulting effects, and the inherent chemical and physical properties of the blend. This review deepens the understanding of the subject matter. Furthermore, the assessments of nano additives contribute to understanding the pollutant emissions from the diesel engine. The incorporation of nano additives with biodiesel and quaternary fuels has led to a reduction in pollutant emissions from diesel engines. This assessment reveals the relevance, stability, properties, and utilisation of the nano additives, ultimately concluding with the suitable percentage of these additives. This process aims to enhance the performance of the diesel engine and improve combustion characteristics through the utilisation of these fuel types2, 230005. 
 https://doi.org/10.4491/eer.2023.005

 (2024).").

The utilisation of petroleum diesel fuel derived from fossil fuels faces two significant challenges: the first challenge is a scarcity of available sources, and the second challenge is the detrimental impact on the natural environment. Biodiesel has garnered considerable acclaim as an environmentally friendly fuel and has become one of the leading alternatives to traditional petroleum-based diesel. Biodiesel is generated through the fermentation of vegetable oils, as opposed to the combustion of fossil fuels. The generation of biodiesel, which can be derived from animal fats, used cooking oil, and oil extracted from microalgae, necessitates the incorporation of long-chain fatty acids as a fundamental input material. It comes from both consumable and non-consumable sources, including rapeseed oil, coconut oil, sunflower oil, soybean oil, groundnut oil, and palm oil. Examples of non-edible oil resources include mahua, castor, cotton, rubber, animal tallow, neem, jatropha, and jojoba. Additional examples encompass mahua, sunflower oil, soybean oil, rapeseed oil, palm oil, coconut oil, and groundnut oil, all of which serve as sources of edible oils[3](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR3 "Bouguessa, R., Tarabet, L., Loubar, K., Belmrabet, T. & Tazerout, M. Experimental investigation on biogas enrichment with hydrogen for improving the combustion in diesel engine operating under dual fuel mode. Int. J. Hydrog. Energy. 45, 9052–9063. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijhydene.2020.01.003

 (2020).").

Methyl ester, sharing numerous physico-chemical properties with conventional diesel, presents a promising alternative as a substitute for diesel fuel. Moreover, diesel engines find extensive application in commercial settings, including on-road vehicles within the transportation sector and off-road vehicles utilised in agriculture and mining. This is attributed to their superior energy transfer capabilities and their status as one of the most economical power sources available. Biodiesel presents significant benefits compared to other renewable sources; however, it also comes with notable drawbacks, including its higher density and viscosity, which can lead to injector choke and reduced engine longevity. Transesterification is regarded as the simplest method for transforming triglycerides into methyl ester. Additionally, as an unexpected outcome of the transesterification process, there is a reduction in the viscosity of vegetable oil. Consequently, alterations need to be implemented to both the fuel and the engine to attain the necessary improvements in engine characteristics[4](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR4 "Atmanli, A. & Yilmaz, N. An experimental assessment on semi-low temperature combustion using waste oil biodiesel/C3-C5 alcohol blends in a diesel engine. Fuel 260, 116357. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.fuel.2019.116357

 (2020)."),[5](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR5 "Abed, K. A., El Morsi, A. K., Sayed, M. M., El Shaib, A. A. & Gad, M. S. Effect of waste cooking-oil biodiesel on performance and exhaust emissions of a diesel engine. Egypt. J. Petroleum. 27, 985–989. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ejpe.2018.02.008

 (2018).").

Various types of additives, including alcohols, cetane improvers, water emulsions, oxygenates, and nano additives, can be integrated with diesel and biodiesel to enhance their properties while also reducing exhaust emissions. These additives are available in various forms and can be utilised alongside diesel and biodiesel[6](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR6 "Verma, P., Sharma, M. P. & Dwivedi, G. Impact of alcohol on biodiesel production and properties. Renew. Sustain. Energy Rev. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.rser.2015.11.048

 (2016). 56:319 – 33."). As noted in[1](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR1 "Agarwal, S., Kumari, S., Mudgal, A. & Khan, S. Green synthesized nanoadditives in Jojoba biodiesel-diesel blends: an improvement of engine performance and emission. Renew. Energy. 147, 1836–1844. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.renene.2019.09.139

 (2020)."), Lipase-enhanced nano-catalysts represent a hybrid approach that combines the biocatalytic specificity of lipase enzymes with the high surface area and reactivity of nanomaterials. This innovative catalyst system is designed to improve the efficiency, reusability, and environmental friendliness of the transesterification process used in biodiesel production. The incorporation of metal additives, alcohols, cold flow improvers, and cetane improvers into biodiesel enhances its physicochemical properties, increases the combustion rate, and diminishes the emissions produced by diesel engines.

The objective of the investigation carried out evaluate the impact of integrating biodiesel with nano catalysts or nano additives on the performance characteristics of diesel engines. The properties of the mixture, such as its pour point, fire point, flash point, and viscosity, were significantly enhanced as a direct result of this. The manufacturing process of nano catalysts involves the use of ceramics and various types of metal oxides, including iron-metal oxides, aluminium-metal oxides, titanium-metal oxides, and carbon-metal oxides. A variety of studies have supported the incorporation of organic manganese additives like copper and aluminium, which could enhance an engine’s combustion characteristics, as well as its torque and braking power output, while potentially decreasing exhaust emissions[7](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR7 "Hawi, M., Elwardany, A., Ismail, M. & Ahmed, M. Experimental investigation on performance of a compression ignition engine fueled with waste cooking oil biodiesel–diesel blend enhanced with iron-doped cerium oxide nanoparticles. Energies 12, 5798. 
 https://doi.org/10.3390/en12050798

 (2019).").

An investigation into the performance metrics of diesel engines and the combustion characteristics observed when utilising biodiesel, diesel, carbon nanotubes, and silver additives[8](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR8 "Gharehghani, A., Mirsalim, M. & Hosseini, R. Effects of waste fish oil biodiesel on diesel engine combustion characteristics and emission. Renew. Energy. 101, 930–936. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.renene.2016.09.045

 (2017)."). The findings indicate that the integration of diesel nanoparticles with biodiesel enhances the brake thermal efficiency by 2%, while also decreasing the fuel consumption by up to 7%. Moreover, the incorporation of biodiesel and diesel nanoparticles resulted in a reduction of CO emissions by 25% in comparison to traditional diesel, along with a 26% decrease in UBHC emissions. The nanoparticles facilitated both of these reductions. Conversely, the amount of nitrogen oxides emitted from the biodiesel-diesel-metal addition was 25.32% higher than that produced by standard diesel.

This study aims to enhance our understanding of the impact of methyl ester-CNT (Carbon Nanotubes) mixtures on the performance parameters of diesel engines. The findings indicated that the application of biodiesel blends led to a decrease in UBHC, CO, and soot concentrations in engine exhaust; nonetheless, there was an observed increase in NO emissions[9](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR9 "Senthilkumar, R., Manieniyan, V., Sukumar, S. & Sivaprakasam Analysis on DI diesel engine with combined multi-walled carbon nanotubes and vegetable oil refinery waste as biodiesel. Arab. J. Sci. Eng. 
 https://doi.org/10.1007/s13369-020-04708-y

 (2020)."),[10](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR10 "Lei, T. et al. Performance and emission characteristics of a diesel engine running on optimized Ethyl levulinate-biodiesel-diesel blends. Energy 95, 29–40. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.energy.2015.11.059

 (2016)."). The findings indicate that the brake power of B20 and B40 blends is lower, whereas the specific fuel consumption is higher in comparison to diesel. This occurred even though the B20 and B40 blends exhibited a greater specific fuel consumption. The findings indicated a decrease in UBHC and CO emissions; however, there was a slight rise in NOx emissions. The presence of oxygen in biodiesel contributed to enhancing the efficiency of the combustion process, leading to a subsequent rise in NO emission generation. Using nano additives in conjunction with biodiesel and quaternary fuels, the current research highlights the significant reduction in the emissions of pollutants that are produced by diesel engines. According to other research, which primarily concentrated on the advantages of biodiesel as a whole and did not particularly include nano additives, this is not consistent with the findings. Although similar tendencies were observed in earlier studies, there was not a thorough investigation into the trade-offs.

Addition of zinc oxide (ZnO) to biodiesel acts as a catalyst and it reduces the time and temperature required for complete combustion and thereby decreases the ignition delay which results in the increase in cetane number. This approach is novel because it identifies as a sustainable alternative for conventional diesel fuel: enhanced with nanoparticles, biodiesel generated from waste cooking oil. The work integrates ultrasonic insertion of nano additives (cerium, zinc, and titanium oxide), transesterification with a lipase-enhanced nano catalyst. The study presents an absolute evaluation of performance, emission of an engine with B20 fuel and TiO2 nano additive and conclusively positively identifies the outcomes as sustainable fuel alternative for conventional fossil fuel in a prime mover.

Using waste cooking oil biodiesel mixed with nano-additives (cerium, zinc, and titanium oxide) by ultrasonic treatment seeks to improve diesel engine efficiency. According to the theory, these combinations will lower hazardous emissions and increase engine performance relative to standard diesel. The effects of these combinations on brake thermal efficiency, brake specific energy consumption, and emissions at a constant engine speed of 1500 rpm are assessed in this work. Supporting their possible use as a sustainable fuel alternative, results demonstrate that the B20 + TiO2 mix displays encouraging decreases in unburned hydrocarbons, carbon monoxide, and smoke emissions.

Although numerous studies have explored the integration of nano additives in biodiesel to improve engine performance and reduce emissions, the present study distinguishes itself through several innovative aspects. The use of nano-additives to enhance combustion, heat transfer, and emission reduction. Nano-metal oxides such as CeO2, ZnO, and TiO2 have shown catalytic properties that promote better atomization, reduce ignition delay, and improve oxidation of unburnt hydrocarbons. This study focuses on evaluating the performance and emission characteristics of WCO biodiesel blended with 25 ppm concentrations of CeO2, ZnO, and TiO2 nanoparticles in a compression ignition engine. The novelty of this work lies in the comparative assessment of different nano-additives in waste cooking oil biodiesel and their practical implications for improving sustainability in diesel engine operations. The study evaluates engine performance and emissions comprehensively using these blends in a standard diesel engine without modifications, thus emphasizing real-world feasibility. From a techno-economic standpoint, the low additive concentration combined with substantial gains in combustion efficiency and emission reduction positions this approach as a promising and scalable alternative to conventional diesel.

Materials and methods

Waste cooking oil was converted to biodiesel by transesterification process with the help of lipase immobilized with Fe3O4 catalyst. This catalyst possesses a few advantageous properties, such as being reusable, non-toxic, immune to the effects of free fatty acids found in seed oils, an organic solvent, and an enhancement of the biodiesel production process. Initially, the necessary amount of lipase immobilised nano catalyst was placed in an airtight glass bottle (550 millilitres) and combined with raw waste cooking (250 millilitres), Fe3O4 nano catalyst (1%), while being stirred by a pellet in a magnetic stirrer at a speed ranging from 850 to 1200 rpm. This reaction was started at a temperature of 20 degrees Celsius with a period of 12 min; this parameter was maintained with the operation of a magnetic stirrer, and then the complete procedure was carried out in a closed environment. During this process of transesterification, the lipase immobilised in Fe3O4 nano catalyst works to drive the reaction and continually break the chain of triglycerides that are present in raw waste cooking oil. At the end of this process, the required quantity of Fatty Acid Methyl Ester (FAME) of raw waste cooking oil was successfully extracted with minimal glycerol, which improves the total yield of the reaction.

 Fuel preparation

Initially, the required amount of lipase-immobilized Fe3O4 nano catalyst was placed in an airtight 550-milliliter glass bottle and combined with 250 millilitres of raw waste cooking oil and 1% Fe3O4 nano catalyst. The mixture was stirred using a magnetic stirrer with a pellet at a speed of 850 to 1200 rpm. Initiated at 20 °C, the reaction was kept in a sealed condition for twelve minutes. The immobilized lipase Fe3O4 nano catalyst helped the waste cooking oil triglycerides to be continuously hydrolysed, thus ensuring effective conversion into biodiesel during the transesterification process. Ultrasonication process

To ensure homogeneous dispersion of nano additives into the B20 biodiesel blend, ultrasonication was performed using a probe-type ultrasonic processor was carried out using a PCI Ultrasonics Model ULTRAMAX-9 L, equipped with a titanium alloy probe of 12 mm diameter, operating at a frequency of 20 kHz and a power of 500 W for 30 min. The selection of a 25ppm concentration for all nano additives was based on prior literature reports[1](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7ref-CR1 "Agarwal, S., Kumari, S., Mudgal, A. & Khan, S. Green synthesized nanoadditives in Jojoba biodiesel-diesel blends: an improvement of engine performance and emission. Renew. Energy. 147, 1836–1844. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.renene.2019.09.139

 (2020)."), which suggested that nano additive concentrations in the range of 20–30 ppm optimize combustion characteristics while preventing nanoparticle agglomeration. Preliminary experiments in this study also validated that 25 ppm provided stable dispersion and notable improvements in engine performance.

Lipase-immobilized Fe3O4 nano catalyst

The lipase-immobilized Fe3O4 nano catalyst, procured from Anna University, was employed for the transesterification process. Immobilization of lipase on magnetic Fe3O4 nanoparticles enhances enzymatic stability, reusability, and catalytic efficiency, facilitating effective biodiesel production from waste cooking oil. The synthesis involves co-precipitation of Fe³⁺ and Fe²⁺ salts, functionalization for enzyme attachment, and subsequent lipase immobilization to ensure catalytic activity and reusability. The MNPs of Fe3O4 are first synthesized by co-precipitation of Fe³⁺ and Fe²⁺ salts in alkaline solution followed by washing and drying to obtain a stable nanostructure. For enhanced enzyme immobilisation, the Fe3O4 MNPs are functionalised with 3-amino propyltriethoxysilane (APTES) or glutaraldehyde to ensure reactive sites are formed for enzyme bonding as shown in Fig. 2. The functionalised nanoparticles are then incubated using lipase enzymes in a phosphate buffer solution to allow adsorption or covalent binding, with crosslinking possible using glutaraldehyde for enhanced stability.

The Fe3O4 lipase nano catalyst that is immobilized with lipase is identified using different techniques, such as Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and vibrating sample magnetometry (VSM), in an attempt to validate its structural stability, enzyme immobilization, and magnetic characteristics. The nano catalyst has good merits in biodiesel production, such as easy separation by magnetism, higher reusability of the enzyme, and higher catalytic activity, showing a likely sustainable process in biofuel production.in our research the biofuel after production is characterised by GCMS and FTIR analysis as shown in Fig. 3(A) and (B).

 GC analysis of biodiesel synthesized from waste cooking oil

This investigation employed precise analytical techniques to determine the fatty acid methyl ester (FAME) profile of waste cooking oil biodiesel. Quantitative analysis was performed using the Turbo Mass Version 5.4.2 software, and gas chromatography (GC) was selected as the primary technique due to its high sensitivity and resolution for FAME detection. The analysis was carried out using an Agilent GC 6890 N system, equipped with a Flame Ionization Detector (FID) and a capillary column HP-88 (30 m × 0.25 mm ID × 0.20 μm film thickness), and specifically designed for FAME profiling.

The GC oven temperature program was set as follows: initial temperature of 120 °C (held for 2 min), ramped at 10 °C/min to 180 °C (held for 1 min), and followed by an increase of 3 °C/min to 240 °C (held for 10 min). The injector and detector (FID) temperatures were maintained at 260 °C and 280 °C, respectively. The carrier gas used was hydrogen, delivered at a constant flow rate of 1.0 mL/min, with a split ratio of 50:1 to ensure optimal resolution. Prior to injection, the acid value was determined using 0.1 N alcoholic phenolphthalein indicator, ensuring the oil’s suitability for methyl ester conversion. Figure 3 (A) presents the GC chromatogram of the extracted FAMEs from waste cooking oil biodiesel. The major components identified included methyl palmitate (\~ 35%), methyl oleate (\~ 30%), and methyl linoleate (\~ 20%), which are known to enhance cetane number and improve combustion characteristics in biodiesel applications.

FTIR analysis of raw waste cooking oil and biodiesel

The FTIR analysis was conducted to verify the transesterification process of waste cooking oil into biodiesel by confirming the disappearance of triglyceride groups and the appearance of ester functional groups, which indicates successful biodiesel formation. The FTIR instrument was employed to analyse the extracted waste cooking oil biodiesel sample for the purpose of this investigation. An omnic software version was utilised for the analysis. The investigation was carried out using a Magna 750 FTIR spectrometer that was outfitted with a Deuterated Triglycine sulphate detector. Additionally, a 7.3 KBr splitter and a Ni Chrome source were used in the process. After determining that the range between 500 and 4000 was appropriate, a resolution of 2 was applied to the FTIR spectrum that can be seen in Fig. 3(B). About 3000–2800 is the important spectrum range that generates chemical inequality between raw oil and waste cooking oil biodiesel. This area is referred to as the fingerprint region.

The steep peaks that may be seen in the range between 3003 and 2850 correspond to an aliphatic CH of a hybridised alkene, as well as a sp2-CH and sp3-CH stretch. In addition, the 1737 frequency peak that corresponds to the stretching of the keto group is associated with the ester. In a similar vein, the stretch in area 1627 substantiates the existence of an unsaturated double bond and does not combine with a keto group. A peak band of 3003, followed by a peak band of 2850, provides the stretching of the methyl ester group. The various spectrum bands were differentiated by a stronger band between 3000 and 2800\. In the spectrum range of raw oil, the peak at 1469 was seen, and methylene groups are deserving of credit for producing it. The various characteristic peaks that were observed in the FTIR spectrum of raw waste cooking oil biodiesel was as follows: olefin group (c = c) at 1627, alkene C-H (Aliphatic) (sp2-CH) was presented at 3003, carbonyl single bond to the ester (O-C = O) was observed at 1731, and lastly, an alkane C-H (sp3-CH) component was shown at 2850\. The existence of saturated fatty acids, a carbohydrate chain, and a -C = O stretch may be deduced from the appropriate absorbance peak for waste cooking oil biodiesel, which is located at 1721\. (esters and acids). An amide group could be the source of the 1570 peaks in the spectrum caused by the waste cooking oil biodiesel extract. Last but not least, an increased peak at 1321 was seen in the retrieved waste cooking oil biodiesel spectra, and it was shown to be connected to the glycerol group (O-CH3). Significant peaks were identified: 1737 cm⁻¹ (carbonyl group stretch indicating ester formation), 1469 cm⁻¹ (methylene group vibration), 1570 cm⁻¹ (amide group), 3003 cm⁻¹ and 2850 cm⁻¹ (sp²-CH and sp³-CH stretches), confirming successful transesterification of waste cooking oil into biodiesel.

 Characterization of cerium, zinc and titanium oxide nano additives

The CeO2, ZnO, and TiO2 nanoparticles used in this work were purchased from a certified commercial supplier to ensure consistency and reproducibility of particle size and quality. SEM analysis was performed to study the surface morphology and agglomeration of the nanoparticles, as these characteristics strongly affect combustion behaviour and catalytic activity when blended with biodiesel. Figure 4 (A, B, C) presents the SEM images showing the morphology of Cerium Oxide, Titanium Oxide, and Zinc Oxide nanoparticles, respectively, with an observed particle size range of 40–80 nm. SEM analysis was conducted to characterize the surface morphology and particle distribution of the synthesised nano additives. The samples were gold-coated using a sputter coater to enhance conductivity and reduce charging effects. SEM imaging was performed using a VEGA3 TESCAN scanning electron microscope at an accelerating voltage of 35 kV. The analysis was conducted under high vacuum conditions (approximately 0.02 torr) to improve image resolution. The secondary electron (SE) detector was used to capture surface topography, with a working distance maintained at 10–15 mm, optimized for depth of field and image sharpness.

The results indicated a uniform distribution of nanoparticles with moderate agglomeration, which is typical of powders synthesized via the sol-gel combustion method. The morphology revealed semi-spherical particles with distinct porous structures, contributing to the formation of nanoscale voids and a larger surface area, which is favourable for additive applications. In pursuit of attaining the desired premium diesel output, this study investigated the performance and emission characteristics of waste cooking oil biodiesel fuel blends with nano additives, without introducing any modifications to the diesel engine. Technoeconomic perspective

The cost of raw waste cooking oil is economically favourable compared to that of virgin oils. Titanium dioxide (TiO₂), used as a nano additive at a low dosage of 25 ppm, is widely available and cost-effective, with its cost remaining marginal when distributed across the total fuel volume. Although ultrasonication requires an initial capital investment, it significantly enhances additive dispersion and fuel stability, thereby reducing maintenance demands and operational issues. Moreover, the reduction in emissions such as CO, HC, and particulate matter (PM) can help lower expenses associated with after-treatment systems and potential carbon penalties[18](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7ref-CR18 "Kalargaris, I. et al.  (2017).").

Our study systematically compares the influence of three individual nano-oxides (TiO₂, ZnO, CeO₂) at a controlled 25 ppm concentration using ultrasonication for dispersion. Most existing studies either focus on a single nano additive or use higher, non-standardized concentrations, often without dispersion stability assurance.

Stability of the fuels

The stability of biodiesel blends containing nanoparticles is critical to ensure consistent combustion performance, injector safety, and long-term storage feasibility. In this study, a qualitative stability evaluation was performed for B20 blends incorporated with TiO₂, CeO₂, and ZnO at 25 ppm concentration using ultrasonication for 30 min at 40 kHz frequency to ensure homogeneous dispersion. Each fuel sample was stored in transparent glass containers at ambient room temperature (≈ 25 °C) for a duration of 30 days, without agitation. The samples were visually inspected at intervals of 1, 7, 15, and 30 days to check for Sediment formation at the bottom, Color changes, Phase separation, Hazy or cloudy appearance.

Observations TiO₂-blended B20 remained visually stable with no visible sedimentation or separation for up to 30 days. ZnO and CeO₂ blends showed slight cloudiness and minimal sediment formation after 15 days, indicating potential early-stage agglomeration. All blends retained color uniformity, suggesting no major phase instability.

 Experimental details

Figure 5 shows the experimental set up for the experimentation. The work was carried out using a Kirloskar single-cylinder diesel engine. Operating at 1500 revolutions per minute, this engine produced 5.2 kW. The injection timing was set at 23° before top dead centre (BTDC), and the injection pressure was maintained at 210 bar throughout the experiments. The important instruments were connected to or permanently attached to the diesel engine so that all of the research tests could be carried out. By adjusting the engine load while keeping the speed constant, we were able to approximate the outcomes of these tests. In the first phase, the diesel engine was run on its standard premium diesel fuel to establish a baseline for the full load scenario and to account for the parameters that were wanted. All the diesel fuel blends tested in this study premium diesel, waste cooking oil biodiesel, and the blends with nano additives were run in the engine without any modifications to achieve the specified output.

The single-cylinder diesel engine (TAF-1) type produced by the Kirloskar brand was used for this in-depth experimental study work. The different diesel engine specifications are summarized in Table 2. A data capture system’s software helped record the combustion parameters of this diesel engine on a personal computer after coupling it with an eddy current dynamometer. Next, a purpose-built software application was used to estimate and analyse the combustion properties of this engine. Located adjacent to the gasoline tank, the fuel control unit was equipped with a pressure sensor that senses the pressure of the engine’s fuel intake. The sensor is a piezoelectric pressure transducer 7063-A type linked with a Kistler instrument. We did this to make the engine run more smoothly. The analyser, encoder, and amplifier were manufactured by the Swiss company Kistler AG to distinguish the different engine input signals.

The engine speed of 1500 rpm was set using a connection between the flywheel, an optical sensor, and a K-type thermocouple. Monitoring exhaust gas temperature was achieved with another K-type thermocouple, while pollutant emissions underwent analysis with the AVL five-gas analyser (AVL444). Specifically, the engine was allowed to run for 20–25 min at each load condition to reach thermal equilibrium. Steady-state was confirmed by monitoring key parameters such as exhaust gas temperature, coolant temperature, lubricating oil temperature, and fuel consumption rate. Data acquisition was initiated only after these parameters remained consistent over a period of time, indicating that the engine had reached a stable operating condition. Following a 20–25 min run on premium diesel to release pollutants, SAE 40 lubricating oil was introduced to enhance the diesel engine’s efficiency. Pollutant emissions were then directed to a nondispersive infrared sensor for analysis, with smoke detected by an electrochemical sensor and NOx emissions monitored by the AVL 437 C type instrument. The diesel engine’s stopping capability was assessed at 0%, 25%, 50%, 75%, and 100% of the input load. The temperature of the ambient air is 32 °C and the humidity of the lab is 74% when experiment was performed under laboratory conditions. The HRR was derived from in-cylinder pressure data using a first-law thermodynamic approach, assuming a single-zone combustion model and incorporating volume variation with crank angle. This model assumes the combustion chamber as a homogeneous zone with uniform thermodynamic properties, which significantly simplifies the calculations while still providing meaningful insights into combustion characteristics.

The justification for this choice lies in its wide acceptance in preliminary combustion analysis, especially for single-cylinder engines like the Kirloskar diesel engine used in our work. It enables the estimation of global combustion trends such as ignition delay, combustion duration, and HRR profile with reasonable accuracy.

However, we acknowledge the limitations of the single-zone model. It does not account for spatial variations in temperature, pressure, or fuel-air equivalence ratio, and it ignores effects such as crevice flows, heat losses to cylinder walls, and stratification. While more advanced multi-zone or CFD models can address these complexities, they require detailed input parameters and significantly higher computational resources.

Uncertainty and repeatability

The maximum tolerable deviation measures the precision of an instrument, which defines how much a quantity measured can be different from the actual or true quantity. In fact, considering variables such as the range of the instrument and extraneous variables, uncertainty is the interval within which the true result will probably fall. For example, the AVL 437 smoke meter has an accuracy of 1%, meaning that its measurement can be off by up to 1% from the actual value. Its uncertainty is also 1%, which is the measurement’s confidence interval. Similarly, the AVL GH14d pressure transducer has an accuracy of 0.1 bar and an uncertainty of 0.15%, which ensures reliable pressure measurements. The precision and reliability of the experimental results were assessed through a detailed uncertainty analysis. Measurement uncertainties were calculated by considering both instrumental errors and procedural variabilities. For calculated performance parameters like Brake Thermal Efficiency (BTE) and Brake Specific Energy Consumption (BSEC), the total uncertainty (U\_total) was obtained using the root-sum-square (RSS) method.

$$\\:\\text{U}\\:\\text{t}\\text{o}\\text{t}\\text{a}\\text{l}\\:=\\sqrt{{U}\{1}^{2}+{U}\{2}^{2}+\\dots\\:.+{U}\_{n}^{2}}$$

Where, U1, U2, U3… Un are the individual uncertainties from contributing parameters. In addition, the reproducibility of measurements has been guaranteed by repeating every test three times to enhance the reliability and lower experimental errors. Considering instrument precision and repeatability, the uncertainty in Brake Thermal Efficiency (BTE) and Brake Specific Energy Consumption (BSEC) measurements was ± 2.5%. Emission measurements (CO, UBHC, NOx) were within ± 3% uncertainty.

 Results and discussion

Performance characteristics of waste cooking oil biodiesel with nano additives

Figure 6A and B present the brake thermal efficiency (BTE) and brake specific energy consumption (BSEC) for the various fuel blends tested. The addition of nano-additives significantly influences the combustion characteristics of biodiesel blends, contributing to improved BTE and reduced BSEC. Among the tested blends, B20 + TiO2 (25 ppm) exhibited the most favourable performance, recording a BTE of 31.21%, which is only 2.53% lower than premium diesel (32%) and 6.05% higher than regular B20 (29.32%). This enhanced performance is attributed to the catalytic nature of TiO2, which facilitates oxidation reactions through oxygen release and surface interaction. Its high surface area improves fuel atomization and evaporation, ensuring more uniform air-fuel mixing and efficient combustion. The presence of TiO2 also reduces ignition delay and enhances in-cylinder pressure rise, leading to improved thermal energy conversion. In terms of BSEC, B20 + TiO2 recorded a value of 12.08 MJ/kW.hr, showing only a 3.80% increase compared to premium diesel (11.62 MJ/kW.hr). This is significantly better than B20 without additives (13.37 MJ/kW.hr) and B100 (highest BSEC). The reduction in BSEC despite biodiesel’s inherently lower calorific value and higher viscosity is due to the improved combustion efficiency facilitated by TiO2. The additive’s thermal conductivity and catalytic action reduce energy losses and promote complete combustion, leading to better fuel utilization. Overall, TiO2 outperformed CeO2 and ZnO, which recorded lower BTE and higher BSEC values. This suggests that TiO2 is the most effective among the tested additives in enhancing engine performance using biodiesel blends.

The maximum brake thermal efficiency was recorded for premium diesel at 32%, and second to this was B20 blended with TiO2 (25 ppm) at 31.21%. This is a drop of 2.53% compared to diesel and an increase of 6.05% over regular B20\. The CeO2 and ZnO blends exhibited a slightly lower BTE of 30.08% and 30.01%, respectively, while B20 without any nano-additives exhibited a BTE of 29.32%. The poorest efficiency was obtained with B100 at 26.9%, which was caused by its high viscosity, low calorific value, and poor volatility, resulting in incomplete combustion and excessive energy losses. The BSEC was the lowest for the high diesel at 11.62 MJ/kW.hr, followed by a value of 12.08 MJ/kW.hr for the B20 + TiO2 (25 ppm) blend, indicating a modest rise of merely 3.80%. The CeO2\-ZnO mixtures recorded slightly higher BSEC values of 12.21 MJ/kW.hr and 12.51 MJ/kW.hr, respectively, whereas B20 was 13.37 MJ/kW.hr, indicating the higher energy demand for biodiesel blends without nano-additives. The study indicates the feasibility of adopting nano-additive-doped biodiesel as a substitute fuel, highlighted on its ability to improve efficiency and reduce environmental footprints with little need for adapting traditional engine systems. While our study notes a slight reduction in BTE (2.53%) and increase in NOX (8.58%) with B20 + TiO2, it also reports significant reductions in UBHC, CO, and smoke emissions, showing improved combustion and cleaner exhaust.

Combustion characteristics of waste cooking oil biodiesel with nano additives

Figure 7(A) shows the in-cylinder pressure variation with crank angle, while Fig. 7(B) presents the corresponding heat release rate (HRR). Premium diesel recorded the highest in-cylinder pressure at 59.86 bar, followed by B20 + TiO2 (58.82 bar), B20 + CeO2 (57.21 bar), and B20 + ZnO (57.21 bar). B20 without additives and B100 recorded 56.97 bar and 54.48 bar, respectively. The near-maximum cylinder pressure observed for B20 + TiO2 reflects better combustion stability due to improved atomization and oxygen diffusion promoted by the additive.

The enhanced combustion process is driven by TiO2’s high thermal conductivity and oxygen buffering capability. These properties promote quicker and more complete combustion, resulting in shorter ignition delay and more stable combustion phasing. The nano-additive’s surface catalysis supports fuel breakdown and oxidation, contributing to elevated in-cylinder pressures with minimal energy loss. The HRR values presented in Fig. 7(B) show a maximum of 71.71 J/°CA for premium diesel, followed by 66.65 J/°CA for B20 + TiO2, and progressively lower values for CeO2, ZnO, and B20\. B100 recorded the lowest HRR. The 7.59% reduction in HRR for B20 + TiO2, compared to diesel, reflects the change in combustion dynamics due to the nano-additive. Despite a lower peak HRR, the broader and smoother release curve indicates more stable and prolonged combustion, which is beneficial for reducing knocking and improving fuel efficiency. In summary, the combustion analysis confirms that TiO2 promotes more efficient combustion through improved atomization, oxygen diffusion, and catalytic effects, helping biodiesel blends to approach the performance of premium diesel.  (2019)."),[22](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR22 "Aydın, S. Comprehensive analysis of combustion, performance, and emissions of power generator diesel engine fueled with different source of biodiesel blends. Energy 205, 118074. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.energy.2020.118074

 (2020).").

The observed improvements in combustion and emission characteristics with nano-additive biodiesel blends can be attributed to the catalytic and oxygen-supplying roles of the nanoparticles. TiO2 nanoparticles act as oxygen donors, releasing oxygen radicals at elevated temperatures and thereby promoting the complete oxidation of CO to CO₂ and HC to CO2 and H2O. CeO2 nanoparticles participate in a reversible Ce³⁺/Ce⁴⁺ redox cycle, functioning as an oxygen buffer that stores and releases oxygen during combustion, which shortens ignition delay and improves combustion completeness.

$$\\text{CeO}\{2} \\leftrightarrow \\text{Ce}\{2}\\text{O}\{3} + 1/2 \\,\\text{O}\2$$

ZnO nanoparticles, on the other hand, act as catalysts by lowering the activation energy of oxidation reactions, enhancing fuel–air mixing, and facilitating faster combustion. Collectively, these mechanisms explain the reduction in CO, HC, and smoke emissions, along with the improvements in thermal efficiency observed in this study.

Cylinder pressure and heat release rate (HRR) analysis revealed a 1.76% reduction in peak pressure and a 7.59% decrease in HRR for the TiO2 blend. These changes are linked to delayed ignition and enhanced atomization caused by the nano additive’s oxygen buffering capacity, which promotes smoother combustion and reduces knocking tendency23 blends operated in a single cylinder diesel engine: performance, combustion and emission characteristics. Energy 215, 119091 (2021).").

Emission characteristics of waste cooking oil biodiesel with nano additives

Emission measurements, including unburned hydrocarbons (UBHC), carbon monoxide (CO), nitrogen oxides (NOx), and smoke, were recorded and analyzed with respect to brake power (Fig. 8A&B and 9A&B). B20 + TiO2 consistently showed the best emission performance among the biodiesel blends. UBHC emissions were reduced by 17.41% with B20 + TiO2 compared to premium diesel, due to enhanced oxidation and complete combustion. The TiO2 additive helps maintain optimal in-cylinder temperatures and prevents quenching effects near the cylinder wall, thereby minimizing hydrocarbon residues. Its catalytic activity promotes degradation of unburned hydrocarbon chains, ensuring minimal UBHC in the exhaust. CO emissions showed a 36.36% reduction with B20 + TiO2. This is due to the high oxygen content and improved oxidation efficiency of the blend, which promotes full conversion of CO to CO2 during combustion. TiO2’s role in reducing ignition delay and improving combustion phasing further ensures lower CO formation. NOx emissions, however, increased by 8.58% with B20 + TiO2, a typical trend in biodiesel combustion due to higher in-cylinder temperatures and increased oxygen availability. Nonetheless, TiO2 produced the lowest NOx among the nano-additive blends. This is attributed to its oxygen buffering capability, which helps regulate combustion temperature and limits localized hot spots. The nanoparticle also aids in more uniform heat distribution, partially mitigating NOx formation. Smoke emissions were reduced by 16.25% with B20 + TiO2 compared to diesel. TiO2 acts as a combustion enhancer, promoting complete oxidation of carbonaceous compounds and reducing soot formation. Improved atomization and fuel-air mixing further contribute to this effect. In summary, TiO2 significantly improves emission performance by lowering UBHC, CO, and smoke emissions while moderately increasing NOx, which can be managed by incorporating exhaust after-treatment technologies such as EGR or SCR systems in future studies. The enhanced catalytic activity of TiO2 nanoparticles facilitates the degradation of hydrocarbon chains more effectively, reducing unburned fuel residues and thus contributing to overall emission reductions[24](ref-CR24 "Subramaniam, M., Solomon, J. The TiO2 nanoparticles also help regulate excess oxygen during combustion, thus regulating the combustion temperature and minimizing NOx formation to some degree. Moreover, better heat transfer properties of TiO2 facilitate efficient energy redistribution in the vicinity of the combustion chamber, reducing localized high-temperature hot spots causing excessive NOx formation shown in Fig. 9 (A). Hence, TiO2 in fuel mixture supports a more uniform combustion reaction with lower nitrogen oxidation than some nano-additive fuel mixtures[29](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR29 "Duraisamy, G., Rangasamy, M. & Hossain, A. K. A study on flexible dual-fuel and flexi combustion mode engine to mitigate NO, soot, and unburned emissions. Fuel 322, 124276. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.fuel.2022.124276

 (2022)."),[30](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR30 "Oni, B. A., Sanni, S. E., Ibegbu, A. J. & Aduojo, A. A. Experimental optimization of engine performance of a dual-fuel compression-ignition engine operating on hydrogen-compressed natural gas and Moringa biodiesel. Energy Rep. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.egyr.2021.01.019

 (2021). 7:607 – 19.").

Correlation of brake power and smoke emission is illustrated in Fig. 9(B), where there is comparative evaluation of smoke emission for tested fuel blends and reference premium diesel. The behavior is said to increase as the percentage of the fuel blend grew, in addition to greater smoke emissions, especially at full load condition. It was, however, noted that the premium diesel recorded maximum smoke emissions when compared to all the biodiesel fuel blends. The smoke emission levels for different fuel blends were 78.4 HSU for premium diesel, 67.44 HSU for B20 + TiO2 (25 ppm), 68.54 HSU for B20 + CeO2 (25 ppm), 68.5 HSU for B20 + ZnO (25 ppm), 71.85 HSU for B20, and 68.8 HSU for B100\. Among these, the B20 + TiO2 (25 ppm) mixture showed an enormous reduction of 16.25% in smoke emissions in comparison to premium diesel under load conditions. The phase of diffusion burning is also improved to prevent the possibility of sooting and providing improved air-fuel mixing to inhibit local zones of fuel enrichment, which characteristically form locations of partial burning. The greater thermal conductivity of TiO2 also promotes more even distribution of heat and prevents local cooling, which reduces temperature drops contributing to soot. These complementary effects are credited with the noticed reduction in emissions of smoke that render B20 + TiO2 (25 ppm) less harmful to the environment compared to regular diesel fuel and other blends of nano-additives[31](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR31 "Rami Reddy, S., Murali, G. & Dhana Raju, V. Assessment of diethyl ether as a fuel additive on the diverse characteristics of diesel engine powered with waste Mango seed biodiesel blend. Int. J. Ambient Energy. 43, 3365–3376. 
 https://doi.org/10.1080/01430750.2020.1824944

 (2022).").

The economic feasibility and scalability of employing nano additives in biodiesel engines remain critical considerations for real-world implementation. Although small quantities (typically 25–100 ppm) of nanoparticles can yield notable improvements in engine performance and emission reduction, the cost of nanoparticle production, particularly for materials like cerium oxide or zinc oxide, can be relatively high compared to conventional additives32, 2560–2577. 
 https://doi.org/10.1080/15567036.2020.1754604

 (2021).").

In addition, the synthesis methods often involving chemical precipitation, sol-gel, or hydrothermal processes may require controlled environments and energy inputs, raising concerns about production scalability for industrial applications. Efforts to develop green and cost-effective synthesis techniques using plant extracts or waste materials are ongoing and may offer a more viable route for large-scale deployment[33](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR33 "Barathiraja, C. et al. Green synthesis of cerium oxide nanoparticles using Moringa Oleifera leaf extract and their application in biodiesel blends. Fuel 279, 118518. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.fuel.2020.118518

 (2020)."),34, 6557–6561. 
 https://doi.org/10.1021/es101792z

 (2010).").

From an environmental standpoint, the lifecycle impact of nanoparticles must be carefully evaluated. While nano additives demonstrate technical benefits, cost optimization, green synthesis methods, and comprehensive environmental assessments are crucial for their large-scale, economically feasible, and environmentally responsible application in biodiesel-fuelled engines[35](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR35 "Sajjad, W. et al. A comprehensive review on the performance of diesel engine using biodiesel and nano-additives. Energy Rep. 6, 3856–3886. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.egyr.2020.10.057

 (2020).").

The present study observed an improvement in BTE and a reduction in emissions such as CO, UBHC, and NOx upon the addition of nano additives (e.g., cerium oxide, titanium oxide) to biodiesel blends. These findings are generally consistent with previous studies. For instance, Sajjad et al.[35](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR35 "Sajjad, W. et al. A comprehensive review on the performance of diesel engine using biodiesel and nano-additives. Energy Rep. 6, 3856–3886. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.egyr.2020.10.057

 (2020).") and Singh et al.32, 2560–2577. 
 https://doi.org/10.1080/15567036.2020.1754604

 (2021).") reported enhanced BTE and decreased emission levels when CeO₂ and ZnO nanoparticles were added to biodiesel, attributing this to improved oxygen availability and catalytic oxidation during combustion.

However, a slight discrepancy was noted in the extent of NOx reduction. While our study showed a moderate decrease in NOx emissions with nano additive use, Barathiraja et al.[33](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR33 "Barathiraja, C. et al. Green synthesis of cerium oxide nanoparticles using Moringa Oleifera leaf extract and their application in biodiesel blends. Fuel 279, 118518. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.fuel.2020.118518

 (2020).") reported a more significant reduction under similar conditions. This difference could stem from variations in nanoparticle concentration, base fuel properties, or engine operating conditions. In our case, the NOx reduction may have been limited due to higher in-cylinder temperatures associated with enhanced combustion, which can offset the NOx suppression effect of oxygenated fuels.

The emission trends also align with findings from Sajjad et al.[35](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR35 "Sajjad, W. et al. A comprehensive review on the performance of diesel engine using biodiesel and nano-additives. Energy Rep. 6, 3856–3886. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.egyr.2020.10.057

 (2020)."), where CO and HC emissions decreased due to better oxidation, but the magnitude of reduction varied. This could be influenced by the nanoparticle size, dispersion method (ultrasonication vs. mechanical stirring), and engine load condition.

The only adverse effect was an 8.58% increase in NOₓ emissions, which is consistent with biodiesel’s inherent oxygen content and elevated combustion temperature. However, the increase in NOₓ was lower with TiO₂ than with CeO2 and ZnO due to TiO2’s oxygen-buffering ability, which tempers the peak flame temperatures.

This is in agreement with findings reported by Sajjadi et al.[35](/articles/s41598-025-17528-7#ref-CR35 "Sajjad, W. et al. A comprehensive review on the performance of diesel engine using biodiesel and nano-additives. Energy Rep. 6, 3856–3886. 
 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.egyr.2020.10.057

 (2020)."), where oxygen-rich nano additives enhanced combustion efficiency while slightly elevating NOₓ due to higher localized temperatures.

Overall, while our results generally align with existing literature, variations in fuel formulation, test engine specifications, and nanoparticle properties contribute to differences in outcomes. These comparisons reinforce the importance of standardized testing protocols and nanoparticle characterization to enable more meaningful cross-study evaluations. While previous research has investigated the influence of individual nanoparticles on biodiesel performance and emissions, the present study advances the field by offering a comparative evaluation of three different nano-additives (TiO2, CeO2, and ZnO) blended with waste cooking oil biodiesel. This comparative approach not only identifies TiO2 as the most effective additive for enhancing combustion efficiency and reducing emissions but also provides deeper insights into the underlying chemical mechanisms that govern these improvements. By combining renewable waste-derived fuel with nano-scale catalytic enhancement, this work contributes novel evidence toward developing cleaner, more efficient, and practically viable biodiesel formulations for diesel engine applications.

Conclusion

The results of the present research anchor the viability of waste cooking oil-based biodiesel mixed with nano additive as a renewable and environmentally friendly fuel compared to traditional diesel fuel.

Experimental investigation revealed that B20 + TiO2 (25 ppm) fuel had enhanced performance and emission properties under single-cylinder CI engine operating at peak load condition at 1500 rpm. Addition of nano additives like Cerium, Zinc, and Titanium oxide led to improvement in combustion efficiency and extreme reduction in harmful emissions compared to premium diesel. B20 + TiO2 exhibited the most encouraging outcome, which emphasizes the significant role played by Titanium oxide in fuel optimization. Nevertheless, such benefits notwithstanding, the research also reflects specific limitations worthy of further study. The B20 + TiO2 (25 ppm) blend has shown slight brake thermal efficiency (BTE) and brake specific energy consumption (BSEC) reduction of 2.53% and 3.80%, respectively, against the premium diesel.
Also, the slight reduction in pressure in the cylinder and in the heat release rate (HRR) were seen at larger crank angles at a rate of 1.76% and 7.59%, respectively. Such fluctuation may be adjusted due to the enhanced atomization and postponed ignition process which result in maintaining stability during combustion. Though these are small variations in the performance parameters, optimization of fuel injection strategy and combustion parameters can offset such losses and provide better efficiency. Long-term engine durability testing will also be essential to determine probable effects of nano additives on engine components with respect to wear and deposit formation. For the emissions, B20 + TiO2 showed a reduction of 17.41% in unburned hydrocarbons (UBHC), a reduction of 36.36% in carbon monoxide (CO) emission, and a reduction of 16.24% in smoke emission when compared to diesel. However, the sole limitation noted was the increase in nitrogen oxide (NOₓ) emissions by 8.58%, a typical defect noted with the use of biodiesel owing to the existence of greater oxygen content and enhanced combustion properties.
While NOₓ formation is more directly associated with high combustion temperatures, methods like exhaust gas recirculation (EGR) or catalytic after-treatment systems can be investigated to avoid these emissions without compromising the fuel’s overall advantages. There also must be further research that confirms the long-term dispersion behaviour and stability of nano additives when they are present in biodiesel so that for sustained performance, it can disperse in an even fuel matrix. Application of nano additives such as TiO2 with waste cooking oil biodiesel at 25 ppm is one potential move towards cleaner and more sustainable fuels. This abolishes the use of fossil fuels and supports the environment through emissions reduction. Still, there are issues involving NOₓ emissions, stability of fuel, and long-term consequences on the engine parts which have to be eliminated in favour of making the blends more comfortable to produce for commercial and large-scale industrial utilization.
The slight increase in NOx emissions with B20 + TiO2 is primarily due to higher combustion temperatures resulting from better oxygen availability and combustion efficiency. However, TiO2’s oxygen buffering property helps minimize localized hot-spots, slightly mitigating NOx compared to CeO2 and ZnO2 blends. Potential challenges like nano additive agglomeration, injector wear, and long-term engine deposit formation are recognized and merit future investigation. Additionally, the use of a single engine type, variability in waste cooking oil quality, and laboratory-scale conditions limit the broader generalizability of findings.
Additional research into the optimization of nano additive levels, and on-board engine testing under different operating regimes, will be necessary in proving the viability and scalability of this fuel blend as an energy source.

New Haven plant now the East Coast’s largest producer of biofuels

by P.R. Lockhart and John Moritz, CT Mirror 
December 1, 2025

 New Haven plant now the East Coast’s largest producer of biofuels by P.R. Lockhart and John Moritz, CT Mirror December 1, 2025 Inside a green metal-clad building in the Port of New Haven, a kind of modern day alchemy is at work, turning used cooking oil into fuel capable of powering trucks and heating homes. Within a maze of tightly stacked tanks, pipes and collection units, workers take the grease — or other available waste products such as animal fats, tallow and vegetable oils — and add an alcohol catalyst to trigger a chemical reaction that produces biodiesel, which is marketed as a more climate friendly alternative to traditional fossil fuels. A series of rapid expansions in recent years has made the plant, home of American GreenFuels, the largest producer of biodiesel on the East Coast. Originally opened in 2011 as Greenleaf Biofuels, the plant was later purchased by the American division of Swiss commodities trader Kolmar Group and renamed American GreenFuels. Since 2016, its output has quadrupled, from 15 million gallons to nearly 60 million gallons a year. The most recent expansion, completed this summer, added a second story to the production floor. "It often smells like french fries, as you might expect," said Paul Teta, the vice president and general counsel for Kolmar Americas, which is based in Shelton. The company's growth has been spurred, in part, by government subsidies and laws requiring fuel dealers to blend home heating oil with biodiesel in an effort to reduce carbon emissions. Teta declined to say how much the company has invested in its New Haven plant, other than to say it was in the "many millions of dollars." According to Kolmar, the biodiesel made at its New Haven facility produces 86% less greenhouse gas emissions, on average, compared with ultralow-sulfur heating oil. The emissions reductions are even more substantial when the fuel is sold and burned in Connecticut, removing the need to transport it long distances on trucks. New York City passed the nation's first blended biofuel mandate in 2012 and was followed by a state laws in New York, Connecticut and Rhode Island. Connecticut's law,",

Used Cooking Oil (UCO) Market Forecast and Outlook 2025 to 2035

The global used cooking oil (UCO) market is projected to reach USD 17.18 billion by 2035, recording an absolute increase of USD 8.62 billion over the forecast period. The market is valued at USD 8.56 billion in 2025 and is set to rise at a CAGR of 7.2% during the assessment period.

The overall market size is expected to grow by nearly 2.0 times during the same period, supported by increasing biodiesel production mandates and growing circular economy adoption worldwide, driving demand for sustainable feedstock alternatives, waste-to-energy conversion technologies, and renewable fuel production across both developed and emerging markets.

Why Does Renewable Fuel Demand Drive UCO Market Expansion?

The used cooking oil market grows by enabling biodiesel producers, renewable fuel manufacturers, and oleochemical processors to access sustainable feedstock alternatives that support production mandates while meeting environmental demand for waste-derived raw materials.

Industrial operations face mounting requirements to implement renewable feedstock sourcing strategies with verified sustainability credentials, with UCO feedstock typically providing superior carbon intensity scores and regulatory compliance essential for competitive operations in biofuel production and green chemistry sectors.

The renewable energy industry's need for diverse feedstock portfolios and consistent supply reliability creates demand for various UCO grades that can provide optimal conversion efficiency, maintain stable quality parameters across different collection sources, and ensure regulatory compliance without compromising process economics or sustainability standards.

Government initiatives promoting circular economy principles and renewable fuel deployment drive adoption in biodiesel refineries, sustainable aviation fuel facilities, and oleochemical manufacturing operations, where UCO utilization has a direct impact on carbon footprint reduction and sustainability performance outcomes.

The biofuel industry's growing focus on waste-based feedstock prioritization and low-carbon fuel production further expands market opportunities, with lifecycle analysis demonstrating measurable greenhouse gas reduction benefits through UCO-based biodiesel utilization, renewable identification number generation, and carbon credit qualification programs.

Collection infrastructure limitations affecting feedstock availability and technical requirements for contamination removal and moisture management may limit accessibility among smaller biodiesel producers and developing regions with underdeveloped waste oil recovery systems and feedstock aggregation infrastructure.

What makes Biodiesel Production the Dominant Application Segment?

-market-analysis-by-application.webp "Used Cooking Oil (uco) Market Analysis By Application")

The biodiesel production segment represents the dominant force in the used cooking oil market, capturing 50.0% of the total market share in 2025\. This established application category encompasses solutions featuring renewable diesel manufacturing capabilities from transesterification and hydroprocessing operations, including first-generation biodiesel plants and renewable diesel refineries that enable sustainable fuel production and consistent quality standards across all biofuel manufacturing applications.

The biodiesel production segment's market leadership stems from its essential feedstock requirements, with UCO capable of meeting diverse fuel specification demands while maintaining high conversion yields and operational reliability across all refining environments.

Within the biodiesel production segment, transportation biodiesel formulations account for approximately 22.5% share, driven by road transportation fuel mandates and fleet decarbonization initiatives. Industrial biodiesel represents 16.0%, serving stationary power generation and industrial heating applications, while marine fuel biodiesel captures 11.5% through shipping industry decarbonization requirements.

The oleochemicals segment maintains a substantial 12.3% market share, serving manufacturers who require sustainable raw materials for soap production, surfactant formulation, and specialty chemical applications. This application offers renewable feedstock alternatives for personal care and industrial chemical manufacturing while providing sufficient versatility capabilities to meet product performance demands and sustainability certification requirements. Within the oleochemicals segment, soap manufacturing accounts for approximately 4.8% share, surfactants represent 4.0%, and lubricants & greases capture 3.5% through industrial and automotive applications.

Other significant application segments include animal feed production utilizing processed UCO as energy-dense feed ingredients, and miscellaneous industrial applications serving specialized requirements. These diverse applications collectively represent the remaining market share, serving niche industrial protocols and specialized conversion processes.

Key advantages driving the biodiesel production segment include:

Established refining infrastructure with integrated feedstock pre-treatment operations that ensure consistent fuel quality production and specification compliance
High conversion efficiency capabilities allowing maximum diesel yield from waste feedstock without significant processing complexity
Proven regulatory compatibility, delivering renewable fuel credits and carbon intensity advantages while maintaining cost competitiveness against virgin vegetable oils
Broad market acceptance enabling straightforward blending integration and fuel distribution across existing petroleum infrastructure

 How does Food Service Lead Source Category Market Share?

-market-analysis-by-source.webp "Used Cooking Oil (uco) Market Analysis By Source")

Food service dominates the source segment with approximately 58.4% market share in 2025, reflecting the critical role of commercial kitchen operations and restaurant networks in supporting global UCO generation and collection infrastructure worldwide. The food service segment's market leadership is reinforced by concentrated waste oil generation patterns, established collection service relationships, and rising participation rates across restaurant chains, hotel operations, and quick-service establishments in developed and emerging markets.

Within the food service segment, restaurants account for approximately 28.0% share, driven by high cooking oil utilization rates and frequent oil replacement cycles. Hotels represent 18.4% through centralized kitchen operations and food service facilities, while cloud kitchens & QSRs capture 12.0% through emerging delivery-focused food service models.

The household segment represents a significant source category through residential cooking oil disposal and municipal collection programs. This segment benefits from growing consumer environmental awareness that drives participation in waste oil recycling initiatives, municipal drop-off programs, and community collection events in environmentally conscious regions. The industrial segment serves food processing facilities, snack food manufacturers, and other commercial food production operations generating substantial waste cooking oil volumes through continuous manufacturing processes.

Key market dynamics supporting source segment growth include:

Food service sector expansion driven by urbanization and dining-out trends, generating concentrated UCO volumes in metropolitan areas
Collection service modernization enabling efficient routing optimization and quality management protocols
Integration of digital tracking systems facilitating traceability and sustainability documentation
Growing emphasis on comprehensive waste management driving demand for complete collection coverage solutions

What are the Drivers, Restraints, and Key Trends of the Used Cooking Oil (UCO) Market?

The market is driven by three concrete demand factors tied to sustainability mandates and circular economy adoption. First, increasing renewable fuel mandates globally create growing demand for waste-based feedstock alternatives, with biodiesel blending requirements expanding by 5-8% annually in major economies requiring comprehensive UCO supply infrastructure. Second, government incentives promoting waste valorization and circular economy principles drive increased collection participation rates, with many countries implementing extended producer responsibility frameworks and waste diversion targets for organic waste streams by 2030\. Third, technological advancements in feedstock pre-treatment and conversion processes enable more effective UCO utilization that reduces processing costs while improving biodiesel yield and quality specifications across diverse refining configurations.

Market restraints include inconsistent collection infrastructure across different regions that can limit feedstock availability and supply reliability, particularly in developing markets where commercial collection services remain underdeveloped. Quality variability and contamination concerns pose another significant challenge, as UCO feedstock requires extensive testing and pre-treatment to meet biodiesel specifications, potentially causing increased processing costs and yield losses. Competition from alternative waste feedstocks including animal fats and vegetable oil processing residues creates additional market dynamics affecting pricing, demanding strategic feedstock sourcing and blending optimization programs.

Key trends indicate accelerated collection infrastructure development in Asia Pacific markets, particularly India and China, where rapid urbanization and food service expansion drive substantial UCO generation growth. Technology integration trends toward blockchain-based traceability systems with digital collection documentation, automated quality testing protocols, and integrated supply chain management platforms enable transparent feedstock verification approaches that optimize sustainability certification and regulatory compliance capabilities. However, the market thesis could face disruption if significant advances in synthetic biology enable cost-competitive production of drop-in biofuels from alternative feedstocks or major policy changes reduce renewable fuel mandates across key biodiesel markets.
